story: Jeremy Corbyn said at the Labour Party conference in Liverpool this week that MPs would vote down any Chequers based Brexit plan and called for the Prime Minister to change her blueprint if she wanted support from Labour.Theresa May has claimed negotiations are at an &ldquoimpasse and is defiantly standing by her controversial Chequers plan which has received criticism from within her party, and from EU leaders at Salzburg.At the conference in Liverpool, Labour Party frontbenchers insisted that they wanted a general election instead of a second Brexit vote, but added all options were still &ldquoon the table should Mrs May&rsquos plan not get through the House of Commons.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said &ldquonobody is ruling out Remain as an option should there be another referendum on Britain&rsquos relationship with the EU, and claimed Labour would only back a deal that met all of the party&rsquos six tests.                Labour's Caroline Flint RIPS into colleagues backing People's Vote                Councillor mocks attempted Remain 'TAKEOVER' for new Brexit voteSpeaking exclusively with Express, Labour Party MP for Don Valley, Caroline Flint clearly outlined why the party could not back another referendum on leaving the EU.She said: &ldquoWe did have a people&rsquos vote in 2016, and I don&rsquot feel any sense that people have changed their minds. They want us to get on with it. The problem with a second referendum is that it will just reopen, I think, all the isions that emerged in 2016.&ldquoWhat I want to see is a reasonable deal that allows us to get on with things, but also concentrate on some of those massive issues that people had around the country where they voted Leave.&ldquoCommunities like Doncaster and&nbspelsewhere&nbspdidn&rsquot feel they were getting a better share of the national wealth that they were entitled to. In all this debate, that isn&rsquot being discussed as much as it should be.Speaking alongside Ms Flint at a fringe meeting on Tuesday evening, Labour peer Lord Adonis described himself as a &ldquohardline&nbspRemainer and a &ldquodemocrat before calling for a People&rsquos Vote.He said: &ldquoThe people cannot betray the people - let&rsquos understand this. The idea the answer to a problem of democracy is no more democracy - we don&rsquot do that with elections. When we lose an election we don&rsquot say, &lsquooh well we are not having any more of those, we lost that, we are giving up&rsquo. What we do is we carry on arguing.Leading Brexit supporter and Labour MP for Vauxhall, Kate Hoey, was adamant that pro-Remain MPs in the Labour Party were &ldquonot going to get a People&rsquos Vote at the end of Brexit negotiations with the European Union.Ms Hoey also warned that it would be nearly impossible for there to be another general election, which Labour frontbenchers were demanding. She said: &ldquoIt&rsquos going to be very difficult to have a general election, even if nobody wants any deal the Prime Minister brings back with, because of the fixed term parliament.&ldquoI think a lot of MPs who might say publicly they might like a general election, but actually, in&nbsppractice&nbspdo they really want it, on both sides?&ldquoThe electorate at the moment is very volatile and no-one can take for granted&nbspthe electorate's vote&nbspand how they are going to vote no matter what they did in the past.Brexit news: Labour MP's discussed whether there should be a People's Vote at conference (Image: EXPRESS&bull)British entrepreneur John Mills commented on whether the People&rsquos Vote was picking up &ldquomomentum. Mr Mills claimed support was rising, but only in London and Canterbury, and not in&nbspWales, the Midlands and the north of England.He said: &ldquoI think for the Labour Party to start supporting having a second referendum is&nbspa very&nbspdangerous course of action and I think the leadership of the Labour Party realise this.Chair of the Brexit select committee, Hilary Benn, admitted that it was &ldquohard to see a majority of MPs coming out to back&nbspa second&nbspvote.He said: &ldquoI don&rsquot know, I think at the moment it&rsquos hard to see a majority for that emerging in the House of Commons. We&rsquove got a long way to go in this process, ironically in a short amount of time.He added: &ldquoI think the best way to get a sensible Brexit negotiated is to have a change of Government. Because if the Prime Minister has boxed herself in and has nowhere to go now&hellipwe would have a very different kind of Brexit if a Labour Government was elected.The prospect of a change of leadership was echoed by Labour&rsquos shadow justice secretary Richard Burgon who said a general election is a real possibility.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos not in Labour&rsquos gift to call for a general election but I think a general election is a real possibility and that&rsquos our preference. If a Labour Government is elected in that early general election then what we&rsquoll do is bring the country together.&ldquoAccept and respect the referendum and secure a Brexit that meets the six tests that Keir Starmer has set out.Labour&rsquos shadow communities and local government secretary, Andrew Gwynne, added that Labour did not want to &ldquoreopen the 2016 referendum result as he called for a general election.Mr Gwynne also claimed the Government had &ldquofailed miserably in negotiations with the EU.The Mayor of Greater Manchester, Andy Burnham made clear the Brexit result must be &ldquorespected, claiming that the best outcome would be a &ldquodeal.Mr Burnham added that there could only be a People&rsquos Vote if &ldquofurther down the line a no deal is looking like a possible scenario and would only be acceptable as a &ldquolast resort.However, Labour MP for Exeter Ben Bradshaw claimed that &ldquopeople&rsquos minds are changing as they see the reality of Brexit &ndash particularly the reality of the prospect of a no deal Brexit.He added: &ldquoThe Government has completely failed to deliver Brexit in a competent way and we are facing the prospect of either a very bad deal or no deal at all which would be catastrophic for our economy.Labour MP Caroline Flint explained why the party should not back a People's Vote (Image: EXPRESS)&ldquoAnd I think in those circumstances, parliamentarians, whatever their political colour, are going to do what they know is in the best interests of their constituents. If the prospect of the choice is between a crash out no deal scenario and another referendum, I think that&rsquos what they would go for.Labour MP for Blackley and Broughton, Graham Stringer, said he did not think there was a majority in the House of Commons for a second referendum on leaving the EU.Mr Stringer said the arguments of those calling for a second referendum did not &ldquostack up. He said: &ldquoI don&rsquot think there will be a second referendum, nor should there be.Ronnie Campbell, Labour MP for Blyth Valley, added that the Labour Party needed to be &ldquovery careful about&nbspa second&nbspvote on Europe.He said: &ldquoIf they are saying it is a vote for a no deal, that might be a different matter, because a no deal, we don&rsquot know what a no deal could look like, we could go off an oblivion.&ldquoBut, not on Europe. We have had that referendum. We are leaving Europe. We have got to leave on the best terms possible. And if the Tories can&rsquot do it, there is a Labour Government there waiting to be in.Kent Labour Councillor Brendan Chilton claimed that Leave would win any future Brexit vote by a bigger majority but warned the party about &ldquoalienating working-class voters from the Labour Party.Prominent Labour politicians have joined calls for a People&rsquos Vote after Brexit negotiations, including the London Mayor Sadiq Khan.Addressing the conference on Wednesday, Mr Corbyn insisted Labour would not overturn Brexit but questioned the conduct of the May Government during the negotiations with Brussels.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.&ldquoThat is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election. Failing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.Additional reporting by Jodie Packwood in Liverpool.

story: Jacob Rees-Mogg is urging the Prime Minister to unite the country behind a &lsquoSuper Canada&rsquo deal (Image: Getty)Echoing former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, the MP for East Somerset launched a damning attack on Mrs May&rsquos Chequers plan in a column in the Daily .Mr Rees-Mogg insisted that opposition to Mrs May&rsquos policy is growing, and warned that continuing to pursue such a deal is &ldquopointless.He wrote: &ldquoEurosceptics to the Right, the Labour Party to the Left and the European Union in front have all stormed at it with shot and shell.&ldquoIt is a plan that neither delivers Brexit nor satisfies those who do not want us to leave, and the opposition to it seems to be growing. title: homework works parents help
story: He thinks he is stupid and that little Amy is clever because she knows all the answers.What he doesn’t realise is that Amy does her homework with her family every night.American comedian Rob Delaney ignited a lively debate when he tweeted: “Why do they give seven-year-olds so much homework in the UK and how do I stop this?I want my kid frolicking and drawing and playing football.”Fellow celebrities Gary Lineker and Jason Manford agreed.Piers Morgan disagreed, calling the arguments “lazy parenting”.I have to disagree too with Mr Delaney and his supporters.Homework is essential for a child’s education because revisiting the day’s learning is what helps to make it stick.So Catastrophe star Rob and Gary Lineker are wrong in attacking compulsory home-work in primary schools.Sure, you’ll get the odd exceptionally bright pupil who will excel just through what she learns at school, despite not having that support at home.But this is very rare.Teaching is not just the teacher’s job.It takes a village to raise a child.Children learn all the time and the environment surrounding them determines how much they learn.Genes play a part in how clever a child is, but how hard they work also matters.Work hard and you’ll learn lots.Work less and you’ll learn less.Don’t make the mistake of thinking homework is for a child to do on their own.When parents use homework to bond and learn together with their child, the child understands that Mum and Dad value learning.And because a child wants to please their parents, the child’s interest in their home-work will grow, year on year.These children can see the benefit of homework and will enjoy doing it because it makes them feel better about themselves.Everyone loves to feel successful.Ten years ago, author Malcolm Gladwell introduced the idea that it takes 10,000 hours of practice to become an expert in something.We get better at what we practise, whether it’s football or maths.Our brains have a working memory and a long-term memory.If your times tables are stored in your long-term memory, you will quickly be able to calculate what it will cost to buy 12 apples instead of two.If that knowledge isn’t there, you’ll have to resort to counting on your fingers.The more knowledge stored in long-term memory, the better equipped you’ll be to think imaginatively and solve complex problems.Homework revisits what you learn at school to cement it into your long-term memory.I do agree that some home-work is pointless.Silly craft projects that involve gluing things together, which the parent will inevitably end up doing, hold no value for me.I also understand why some parents don’t like homework — they feel that it’s a battle.Parenting is hard.I get that.But we need to stop thinking of homework as a chore that the child is sent off to do, cutting into the parent’s precious time with them.It shouldn’t be the case on Sunday night that Mum says: “Oh God, it’s homework time — let’s get it over with.”Instead, learning should be part of daily le, and an enriching time for both the parent and the child.Reading with your child for 20 minutes should not be a chore.Asking them to count peas on their plate should not be hard work.While you’re out in the street, talk to them about the world around them.This is the sort of homework that is often set for very young children and it can be done without making it feel like a formal lesson.It doesn’t need to be half an hour sitting at a desk.It can just be ten minutes of enjoyable time together.Homework can be written down but can also be spoken or done online, leaving little marking for the teacher.Secondary-school homework can help you learn with your child.You can learn some French again or be reminded of the beauty of Shakespeare!How wonderful is that?By scaffolding the support at home, you can gradually wean them off it, just like taking off bike stabilisers.Eventually, they learn to work independently, so that when they get to GCSEs, they will be in the habit of doing their homework each night.If you don’t get them into the homework habit from an early age, you risk having a battle with a stroppy teen as they approach their exams.And no parent wants that.Those who are against homework will argue that their children have no time for other hobbies.This is nonsense.Children generally finish school at 3.15pm, and younger ones tend to go to bed at about 8pm.That’s nearly five hours of free time.Are they really spending it playing hockey or going to Brownies?I doubt it.Half an hour of homework in five hours of spare time is a drop in the ocean, leaving lots of time for other things.The real worry for parents should be how much time children are spending on social media — something that is so very dangerous and takes up hours of their time, unlike homework.Katharine Birbalsingh is head of Michaela Community School, North London, and has been dubbed the country’s “strictest head teacher”.She introduced an ultra-disciplined approach to learning called Tiger Teaching.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn leave betray class
story: If selling out Leave voters doesn’t bother you then yes, Michel Barnier and Martin Selmayr — the German bully running the show — will delightedly hear how you intend to achieve it.Which explains why they were so keen to give him an audience yesterday.Betrayal is very much in Corbyn’s plans, as he made clear at his conference.Not only because his party is now firmly behind a second referendum with “Remain” as one of the options.But because he is also determined to stay in the EU’s Customs Union — and thus not leave at all.So, in the unthinkable event of a Labour Government seeing Brexit through, it would do so not via tough negotiations.It would be done by immediate capitulation to Brussels’ demands that the world’s fth biggest economy remain forever under their control.We would be barred in perpetuity from signing trade deals with the faster-growing giant economies of the wider world — and the central economic case for Brexit would be destroyed.So while Corbyn now suddenly claims to care for the forgotten working-class communities who backed Leave, they must never forget this: Labour is now controlled by its middle-class London Remainer membership, all desperate to overturn or negate Brexit.WE’LL be blunt, Becks.It is repugnant to see a celebrity smugly dodge justice solely thanks to being rich enough for a fancy lawyer skilled at exploiting loopholes.Especially when that star freely admits doing 59mph in a 40 zone.Millions of ordinary people grimly suck up fines they can ill afford for far lesser speeding offences.Even  their prosecution letter arrives a day late.Beckham may be within the letter of the law, but not its spirit.That’s a bad look for a man desperate for public adulation and establishment approval.Knighthood? It’s crashed and burned.WE hope the poll revealing voters in ­marginal seats deserting the Tories over sky-high rents is enough to stir the ­Government from its paralysis.The Tories are consumed by Brexit.But away from that they must wake up and present radical ideas to beat ­Corbyn’s, especially on housing.They have an advantage.Theirs are more likely to be sane.And vanishingly less likely to put hundreds of thousands on the dole.But Theresa May must realise that voters have more pressing problems than Brexit which could cost her power.Next week the Tories must have a new story to tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david beckham nick freeman mr loophole speeding
story: The footie star admitted driving at nearly 60mph in a 40mph zone - but avoided punishment because prosecutors sent him notice of the offence a day late.His lawyer Nick Freeman - dubbed Mr Loophole for his track record of getting celebs out of trouble - said that from a moral standpoint Becks should have been found guilty.And he called on the Government to change the law which lets speeding drivers escape justice because of minor errors by the prosecution.Mr Freeman told the BBCs Today programme: It was made quite clear from the very start that Mr Beckham didnt dispute that he was speeding.Anyone who accepts that they were the driver and they were speeding, you would think in the normal course from a moral standpoint they should be convicted.But  the law of the land, the law laid down by our Government says no actually...The lawyer insisted the case would help the public by making people more aware of the laws they can use to dodge speeding fines.But he added that MPs should vote to close the loophole  they want to bring more rogue drivers to justice.Mr Freeman said: What Parliament needs to do is it needs to change the law.And he also took a dig at prosecutors - suggesting they were targeting Mr Beckham because of his fame and saying an ordinary Joe or ordinary Jane would never have been taken to court.The former England captain was caught doing 59mph in a 40mph at the wheel of a £200,000 Bentley in January this year.But the notice that hed be prosecuted didnt arrive until 15 days after the offence took place - one day after the two-week deadline.Mr Freeman convinced a judge to throw out the case because of the blunder, leaving Mr Beckham very relieved.Road safety campaigners blasted the verdict and said the football legend should have set a better example.

title: cottingley fairies hoax auction
story: But there was a brief period when millions of Brits genuinely did believe in fairies... and they had the photos to prove it.These shots, known as the Cottingley Fairies photos, were taken by two young girls who claimed that they had seen real-le fairies floating around their garden.And now, over a century since the famous photos were taken, they are going to be put up for auction, continuing the strange and twisting tale of the Cottingley Fairies.When the shots were first printed in newspapers in 1920, some dismissed them as a silly prank while other esteemed members of society - including Sherlock Holmes author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle - insisted they were the real deal.For a while, millions were convinced that the shots proved the existence of the mythical beings, and the bizarre chain of events which followed ided society right down the middle.Like many young girls, 16-year-old Elsie Wright and her nine-year-old cousin, Frances Grfiths, believed in fairies.But when they came back from the bottom of their garden with what looked like hard evidence of the creatures existence, everyone else started to believe too.The girls, from the village of Cottingley in Yorkshire, claimed they had taken two photos of the fairies parading around the lawn, with one shot, taken in 1917, even appearing to show Elsie interacting with a winged gnome.Another shows four of the creatures dancing past Frances face, with one appearing to play a trumpet.Elises dad, a keen photographer, believed the photos were clever fakes. But in 1920, Elsies mum, Polly Wright, took the pictures to a mythical research group called the Theosophical Society to be investigated.Leading society member Edward Gardner was instantly taken with the photos. He blew them up into prints and started selling them at his talks.Then, in 1920, keen spiritualist and Holmes author Arthur Conan Doyle came across the photos while he was researching a magazine article about the creatures.He believed they were real and when he published them, he created a national controversy which left some of the most esteemed scientists and thinkers of the time earnestly arguing whether fairies really do exist.Fairy buff Edward Gardner was also convinced. He went to visit the Wright family and set the girls up with a camera so they could capture more evidence.In the summer of 1920, they took three more images of themselves with the fairies, fuelling more interest in the bizarre debate.Doyle also contacted photo company Kodak, asking expert technicians to examine the prints for signs that they had been tampered with.The response was that the photos showed no signs of being faked, although Kodak refused to provide a certicate of authenticity. Doyle maintained that they were real.Newspapers soon picked up on his claims, with some writers agreeing that the photos seemed legitimate, while others poured scorn on the supernatural shots.Some sceptics noted that the fairies looked too traditional to be real, as  they had been plucked out of a nursery rhyme, while other criticisms included the claim that the fairies hairstyles were suspiciously fashionable.Knowing children, and knowing that Sir Arthur Conan Doyle has legs, I decide that they have pulled one of them, one critic wrote.With nobody able to agree, the story eventually died down, only to be reignited decades later with a spectacular twist.In 1966, a reporter tracked down Elsie, who admitted that the fairies might have been figments of my imagination.Frances was also tracked down and quizzed about the photos. A rational person doesnt see fairies, she admitted, but she claimed the photos were genuine nonetheless.However, the cousins eventually confessed that the pictures were a hoax, and that they had made the fairies themselves, before throwing their props into a river to hide the truth.Elise and Frances, by that time old women, conceded in 1983 that they had drawn the mythical beings onto cardboard, cut them out and then arranged them in the garden with hatpins to make them stand up.Bizarrely though, Frances then claimed that one of the five photos - showing a cluster of fairies wading around long grass - was never faked, even though the others were.She also claimed at one point that she really had seen the fairies in real-le, but then staged the photos so she had evidence.Later, in 1985, Elsie revealed why she had gone along with the prank for so long, saying she had been embarrassed about fooling Conan Doyle and didnt want to show him up.Two village kids and a brilliant man like Conan Doyle – well, we could only keep quiet, she said.Frances added: I never even thought of it as being a fraud – it was just Elsie and I having a bit of fun and I cant understand to this day why they were taken in.A year later, Frances died, and Elsie followed in 1988. However, their hoax remains commonly thought of as one of the greatest ruses of the 20th century, and the legacy of their photos lives on today.Expected to sell for at least £2,000, the first two Cottingley Fairy photos are being auctioned off in Gloucester on October 4, when a new owner can get their hands on a piece of history - and a little bit of real-le magic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sizzling summer and cheap mouse traps have sparked a plague of maggots in the uk
story: A plague of MAGGOTS is sweeping the nation after the warm weather caused a surge of infestations in homes up and down the country.The scorching temperatures have provided flies with the perfect nesting conditions, meaning their offspring &#8211 maggots &#8211 have been hatching and thriving in record numbers.But that&#8217s not the only problem.Now temperatures are dropping, rats and mice are are retreating inside, and homeowners are killing them with shop bought poisons.The rodents are then dying in the walls and vents of houses &#8211 and flies are feeding on them and nesting in their corpses.&nbspNow, more and more Brits are finding nests of maggots in their homes.The soft white wriggly worm-like larvae can hatch in as little as 24 hours in the heat &#8211 and live for five days before turning into flies.Peter Higgs, who runs PGH Pest Control and Prevention, tells Sun Online he has received an unprecedented number of call outs to deal with maggots over the past week.“We’ve had at least a hundred calls over the summer. That’s more than double what we’d normally receive,&#8221 he says.&#8220It’s not just maggots in bins, they’re dropping from the ceiling in homes and shops.”And Peter says we are ALL responsible for the maggot population explosion.“Britain’s hot summer has meant there was a healthy fly count. We’ve all been outside in the garden or parks for picnics,&#8221 he tells Sun Online.“When food gets left in the heat it rots quicker as bacteria forms much faster in warm temperatures. It’s a feasting ground for flies.“It means that maggots are hatching in gardens, bins and also on dead animals around suburban homes and gardens.”According to Peter, home and business owners are only now discovering they are living with maggots thanks to the recent drop in temperatures.“Rats and mice aren’t stupid. If a building isn’t rodent proof they know how to get in out the cold.&#8220The problem is, when well-meaning homeowners put down DIY poisoning they&#8217ll die in the walls – but flies lay their eggs on those rotting corpses.“This week we’ve been called out to an opticians with maggots falling from the ceiling in the client waiting area. That was as the result of a dead animal in the vents.“A restaurant also had to temporarily shut up shop because maggots were dropping down into their customers&#8217 food. It is distressing for everyone involved.”Maggots can be killed with boiling water – but pest control experts advise to always look for the reason behind why the maggots hatched in the first place.Peter’s advice is simple: “As disgusting as they are there is always an even more sinister reason you’ve got them. Identy that and you’re sorted.“It could be a dead pigeon in the roof or a poisoned rotting mouse under the floorboards. &#8220Flies love bacteria-spewing corpses and will lay dozens of eggs on them.“If they are in your bins – you need to make sure clean them out regularly, with a disinfectant. They need a good seal and ensure that rubbish is properly bagged up.“Finally make sure your building is pest proof.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: inside filthy subway hull zero hygiene rating
story: A report on the branch in St Stephen’s Shopping Centre in Hull highlighted ious hygiene problems with the fast-food outlet, including evidence of flies in the preparation area.Alarming pictures taken of the Subway branch show the extent of the filth with what looks like food splattered on the work surfaces that hasnt been cleaned up.In one image discarded food is scattered all over the floor while in another what looks like dirt is stuck to the wall.A sign was also put up over a sink telling staff not to use it.The report, obtained by the Hull Daily Mail, said: “Evidence of flies were found in the sandwich preparation area and in the rear storage/pot wash area.These pests carry food poisoning bacteria and can contaminate food surfaces that they land on.”It also criticised the cleanliness of the premises, saying its standard was “generally poor”.An inspector said: “A thorough deep clean and disinfection is required. All areas must be maintained in a clean condition.”Inspectors swooped on the premises after receiving a complaint about a lack of hot water on the premises.The unnamed inspector said: “There was no supply of hot water to the sinks and wash hand basins at the premises due to a fault with the boiler.“A supply of constant running hot and cold water must be provided in order to allow for effective cleaning of the premises and hand washing to be carried out.”Inspectors also highlighted the branch’s poor stock rotation after a container of porridge oats was found to have an expired best before date.After it was inspected the branch was given a zero hygiene rating.The branch was then voluntarily down.According to the paper, the chain has vowed to seek a re-inspection once all the issues in the report have been rectied.A spokeswoman for Subway told The Sun: We have clear expectations and procedures in place to ensure that stores serve products that meet our food safety standards.Immediate action was taken regarding the issues highlighted and were rectied two months ago.The Environmental Health Officer has confirmed that all works have been carried out to their satisfaction and will re-visit the store once three months have passed, and we look forward to their next inspection.All staff have received hygiene and food safety re-training in Food Safety Levels 1 and 2.The Sun has contacted Hull Council for comment.

title: angela merkel wants to stop britain thriving after brexit david davis blasts
story: The former Brexit Secretary said only French president Emmanuel Macron is taking a harder line against the UK than the German Chancellor, accusing them of being ‘emphatic about us not being seen to succeed’.Speaking to the Evening Standard on the eve of Tory conference, Mr Davis predicted the negotiations will “go the distance”, with any trade deal being clinched only at the last minute.The ex-Cabinet minister also branded the Salzburg summit, where the Prime Minister’s Chequers pan was mauled by EU leaders, a “collective cock-up ... on both sides”.But he reserved his anger at the impasse in the talks on getting an agreement hammered out for Mr Macron.Mr Davis pointed the finger firmly at Paris for “playing hardball”, saying there are three “strong elements” driving its policy.He said one was the “daft argument” that it will only encourage others  the UK gets a good deal.The second: “Is a very, very narrow French one of trying, as it were, to raid our economy to get businesses to go to France.”And the third is the “hysterically wrong” French view of “what they think of us as deregulatory ‘Wild West’ Anglo-Saxon approach to economics”.The 69-year-old, who stood down in July over Mrs May’s draft proposals, also hit out at Ms Merkel.He said: “I don’t think Merkel was ever really going to be our champion, ever, ever … neither Macron, nor Merkel.”Elsewhere in the interview he said Mrs May has to show the Tory conference in Birmingham she is “tough enough to stand up” to Brussels.But he warned of more Brexit turmoil ahead, stressing it is “tough now but it will get tougher” as the countdown to the end of Article 50 approaches.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david beckham lawyer mr loophole
story: Once again he lives up to it after helping David Beckham escape prosecution yesterday – even though he accepted the ex-England captain was speeding.His tactic? He proved that Becks’ notice of prosecution had arrived a day later than it should have. Mr Loophole – real name Nick Freeman – is the lawyer of choice for celebrities who want to get off a driving charge .Sir Alex Ferguson avoided being punished for driving on the hard shoulder of the motorway after Freeman argued in court that the former Manchester United manager was having a “squeaky bum time”, desperately driving to use the Old Trafford toilet while suffering an upset stomach.No stranger to controversy, the lawyer caused a furore this year after suggesting that women who didnt want to be upskirted should “should dress more conservatively”.“The more provocative the attire,” he argued, “the greater risk of someone wanting to have a sneaky view.”Freeman clearly loves his job. He’s written before that loop-hole hunting has left him “almost shaking with excitement ”.If youre a Peeping Tom, or any other kind of law-breaker, in need of help, Freeman could probably mount an effective defence –  you can afford his astronomical fees.But helpfully, Freeman wrote a book, called, of course, The Art of The Loophole.It details his sneaky legal knowledge that has got the likes of Ronnie OSullivan, Sir Alex Ferguson, Freddy Flintoff and Charlotte Crosby off the hook.So  you cant afford thousands, here are some tips from his book that will help you beat the rap.As a rookie prosecutor, he lost a drunk-driving case because hed hadnt submitted a printout of the breathalyser record, only getting a police officer to say the reading in court. If you want to escape law, you should check  the prosecution has followed the law and submitted its evidence correctly. Any little cock-up by them could be your ticket to freedom.Having saved Fergie his licence by arguing for the poor state of the Scotsmans bowels , he thinks medical reasons can be a strong defence.If you couldnt blow into a breathalyser because you had a cold, “then it could be recorded on the station’s CCTV. And there may be ious officers who might remember whether or not you were sneezing or coughing.” But “you can’t simply make it up,” he counsels. “Otherwise you waste my time and your money”.“You might think that in our over-scrutinised, flash-happy age of the speed camera, proving the identity of the driver in a motoring case is fairly easy,” Freeman says. “Not so.” Having got footballer Ashley Ward off a speeding rap by arguing the prosecution couldnt prove the identity of the driver. “If a policeman doesn’t ask for some kind of concrete ID, such as a driving licence with a photo, he leaves himself wide open to being unable to confirm identity,” advises Mr Loophole, having seen the Crown lose many cases because lazy coppers didnt ask for official identication.He recalls another case: “Court papers referred to my client as exposing his penis. He claimed that it was his testes. Could the Crown be sure beyond reasonable doubt that they could ID his anatomy?”Don’t blab your story, even to your solicitor. “It’s not my job to prove he wasn’t disqualied,” he writes of a case, “it’s the Crown’s to prove he was”. So dont admit to any possible wrongdoings to a lawyer – and possibly compromising them – and just let them see  the Crown can make a case against, and there may be “a whole assortment of defects in the paperwork alone that might stop them from doing that.”When Lee Bowyer was convicted for speeding, allegedly peaking at 132mph in his Porsche, Freeman noticed slight dferences in the officers four reports. This weakened the case enough to help him to get the Crown to accept a plea of speeding at 99mph, giving Bowyer a ban of only six weeks and no penalty points. Similarly, Dwight Yorke was pulled over for allegedly driving at 102mph, but the officer made seven subsequent changes to his first report – making for a shaky case that resulted in only a fourteen-day ban.Freeman advises that we always check the small print: “wherever you get paperwork, human error isn’t lagging far behind.” The most common errors being “names are misspelt, or wrong addresses or dates are recorded, notices or,” as happened with Beckham this week, “summonses arrive after the allotted time for their dispatch has expired.” Each and any error is a possible escape route from conviction. “The trick then is to be able to spot such errors. There’s no real skill here – just a laser-like focus.”Freeman once got a client off the hook after hed refused to take a breathalyser test following crash that devastated a family. The police failed to charge him for his refusal, wanting to get him to take a blood test – the results of which were inadmissible because the rules hadnt been obeyed. “If the police had followed the correct protocol my client would have been convicted,” admits Freeman. “It was because of this error – this loophole – that he walked free.”A brilliantly successful lawyer, Freeman focuses on making sure the Crown has done its job properly.If it hasnt then whether you did or didnt commit a crime doesnt matter. No case is too big to fail  they havent made it properly, and can be beaten just by looking for the largely minor mistakes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: slum landlord brent 20 tenants house
story: Landlord Pathanchaly Anandamohanadas, 69, admitted he owned the three-bed semi-detached property crammed with Romanian builders.Outside his £500,000 home in Letchworth, Herts, he refused to say when he last inspected the property or  he knew over a dozen men were living inside.The local authority raided the house at 5am on Thursday and discovered over 20 men living in “appalling and unsafe” conditions.Anandamohanadas laughed at photos from the raid but said “no comment” when asked  he was sorry about the conditions his tenants lived in.He added: “I have rights, I ask that you respect my freedom and my civilisation.”At the property in Brent, north west London, a Romanian tenant confirmed he had lived inside the house for a month.The disgusting conditions, for which the men were paying between £30 and £50 to live in, also had faulty smoke alarms, poor ventilation and fire hazards.The tenant said: “I was there when the police raided at 5am, I have lived there for a month and pay around £50.“My friend told me about the house, I don’t see what the problem is with living there. It’s a bit cramped, a bit tight, but it’s fine.”Today Anandamohanadas told The Sun he had no idea his property had been raided.He said: “This is the first I’ve heard of this. I was there at 10am yesterday.”In stark contrast to the property he rents to tenants making £1,000 a week, his immaculate home lies in a quiet cul-de-sac in Letchworth, Hertfordshire.A white Toyota Rav 4 in the driveway and the house has large extension with a private garden.Outside the rented property occupied by Romanian builders a tenant said: “I sublet from another tenant. I’ve been in the UK since 2010 so I’m kind of a British citizen.”Furious neighbours Karson Mepani, 64 and his we Manbai, 62, have complained to the council about the slum housing and claim food and cigarette butts are thrown into their garden.They also claim their Romanian neighbours play loud music from 10pm at night and are regularly heard fighting and shouting between each other in the house.Karson Mepani said: “It has been let out for the past two or three years.“But the landlord does not know about what the letting agent is doing.“They play loud Romanian music from 10pm until the early hours especially on Saturdays, the noise is dreadful.“We also regularly hear them fighting inside, shouting and screaming at each other.“We are p****d off, I would not mind 50 people living next door  they weren’t so noisy.“Several times we have had food and cigarette ends thrown into our garden.“They are also hanging clothes out to dry on the fence between our houses.“They are disruptive neighbours and we are delighted that someone is finally doing something about it.”A spokeswoman for Brent Council said it was one of the worst illegal HMOs it has uncovered.She said: Aside from seeing rodents or cockroaches it is one of the worst we have seen.The loft was just appalling - really awful conditions.

title: how boris gove sajid and more are using tory conference to launch their leadership campaigns because theyre convinced may is toast
story: Bookies predict the gathering which starts on Sunday will be Theresa Mays last as PM - Ladbrokes is offering odds of 4/6 that a new leader will be in place within a year.So several of the top candidates to replace her are now competing to boost their popularity with activists and their fame among the public.Well-known Tories are planning to speak at multiple fringe meetings, setting out their vision for Britain and their election pitch.Here we profile the top candidates who are clamouring for position over the four-day conference.Boris Johnson is the bookies favourite to take over from Theresa May - with odds of 10/1 that hell be the leader a year from now.At the party conference hes keeping his powder relatively dry, doing just one fringe event.But that meeting - in a hall with a capacity of 1,000 - is set to be one of the standout moments of the conference.Boris will be keen to prove hes still a superstar among the Tory faithful who have the last say on who will succeed Mrs May.Michael Gove, who as Environment Secretary is hailed as one of the most dynamic Cabinet ministers, is listed to speak at least five times.He is attempting to burnish his green credentials by appearing at events hosted by farming and environment groups.Mr Gove hopes that developing a pro-environment image will help him with swing voters around the country.Sajid Javid is seen as the frontrunner for the leadership among ministers who voted Remain in the EU referendum.As well as making a speech from the conferences main stage, hes expected to appear at a number of carefully picked fringe events.He will address one meeting debating the importance of law and order - his current brief as Home Secretary.And crucially, Mr Javid is helping to host a reception for MPs elected since 2015 - who could hold the key to the next leadership election because theyre seen as being less committed to a particular candidate already.Liz Truss, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, is fast developing a reputation as the Cabinets resident Tigger because of her upbeat demeanour and raft of policy ideas.Shes now regarded as a dark horse for the leadership, with her quirky Instagram account gaining her fans from among young activists.Ms Truss is speaking at several fringe events - mostly aimed at promoting free-market ideas and appealing to the youth.Priti Patel was forced to quit the Cabinet last year after meeting Israeli politicians in secret.But she still harbours leadership ambitions and hopes to overtake Boris and Mr Gove among Brexiteers.So she is appearing at a number of high-profile fringes, including a pro-Brexit rally and a think-tank debate on the future of Conservatism.Amber Rudd is another ex-minister who still hasnt given up on the aim of making it to 10 Downing Street one day.As a former Home Secretary, she is an expert on immigration and security policy - two of the most important areas for the Tory grassroots.Ms Rudd is speaking on security in the internet age at one fringe, and attending two talks on migration.Jacob Rees-Mogg was the main attraction at last years conference, with every event he spoke at packed out with adoring activists.This year hes dialled it back a bit - but hes still scheduled to speak at seven dferent fringes.Observers will be keen to see whether he still has the same star power as he did a year ago.

title: school close early friday birmingham
story: The head teacher said he would save the cash-strapped school £18,500 by shaving an hour and 20 minutes off every Friday.The school day will still finish at 3:20pm Monday to Thursday at St Peter and St Paul RC Junior and Infant School.On Friday all 210 students go to a whole-school assembly with the head teacher Neil Porter at 1pm and parents come at 2pm.Porter says teachers now have more time to plan their lessons.The Erdington school also saves money by not having to pay supply staff to supervise children.Mr Porter said: It was probably the most challenging thing Ive had to do as a head teacher, as lots of my parents work and we are not in an affluent area, so they were very concerned about the impact.However, parents have complained about how they have had to change their work schedules.Mum-of-three Juliette O’Donnell said she had to cut her hours at work and her husband now has to work weekends.She told the BBC: “That early finish has meant parents having to take a pay cut as we have done, or having to pay extra for additional childcare.”Grandmother Brenda Keeley said the cutbacks are awful.She added: “If it wasn’t for me picking up my granddaughter, my daughter would have to give up work all together.”Another disgruntled parent, Rob Stinton, says he now works longer hours Monday to Thursday so he is able to leave early on a Friday.He said: “It’s hard but we have to do what is best for the children’s education,  that’s what it takes.”The change also means the pupils lunch is five minutes less at lunch and they stay five minutes longer Monday to Thursday.Teachers spend the extra time on Fridays at school for planning, preparation and assessment, which they have to do.Porter says the total budget for the school is £970,000, which was cut from last year’s £983,000.These measures have made it possible to cut the budget deficit for the school from £26,000 to £4,000.This is not the first school in Birmingham to cut their school days.Anderton Park School in Sparkhill has shaved 45 minutes off their finishing time.Head teacher Sarah Hewitt-Clarkson said: “Early finishes are definitely more and more prevalent at schools now.“We are slowly sinking.”The government said Birmingham received £909million for the 2018-2019 school year, which is a £4million increase from 2017-2018.A Department for Education spokesperson said:“We know that we are asking schools to do more, which is why we are helping them to reduce the £10 billion spent each year on non-staffing costs, providing government-backed deals for things like printers and energy suppliers that are helping to save millions of pounds.”

title: dad dodged child support decade caught 125k postcode lottery win tv
story: Stella Davis, 44, was stunned to spot grinning Richard Bailey, 43, being handed the massive cheque.The barmaid and son Owen, 17, have not seen the lorry driver since 2008 and she claims he owes her £3,065.22.Stella had no idea where he was living until she saw him and new we Lisa, 44, being handed the cheque by former X Factor star Danyl Johnson last Sunday.Richard says in the ad: “Brilliant. Time for a party I reckon.”Stella told The Sun: “We haven’t heard from him in ten years, not even a Christmas card.“The Child Support Agency has been chasing him but the only payment was £5.57 three years ago.” Student Owen added: “I was speechless. I’d forgotten what he looked like.”Stella, of Godalming, Surrey, split from Richard when Owen was 18 months old.She said he cut off all contact when he got together with Lisa and moved away.Stella vowed to chase her ex-husband for the money he owes.Last night Richard, of Mansfield, Notts, declined to comment.A spokeswoman for the Department for Work and Pensions said they do not comment on inidual cases.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: squalor in designer dog trade
story: In her book Designer Dogs: An Exposé Inside The Criminal Underworld of Crossbreeding, she lts the lid on the suffering inflicted on these “Frankendogs” by cruel breeders.Here, Madeline, president of animal charity SPCALA, shares some of her horric finds.HE was destined to become someone’s new best friend.The four-week-old puppy had been found a loving home and was all ready for collection with a sign strung round his neck saying: “Sold, pick up Sunday.”But there was a problem. He was dead.The tragic cockapoo — a mix of the cocker spaniel and poodle — was just the latest casualty of a growing global demand for fashionable hybrid pets.The mostly criminal market to supply these designer dogs leaves a trail of horrendous abuse and suffering, with animal lovers often unaware of the high cost of cute.A look inside unlicensed puppy farms reveals dogs whose coats are stained yellow from lying in their own waste. Mothers in crammed cages suckle their puppies — both dead and alive.And those who are considered not cute enough to make the grade are suffocated, battered to death or left to die in a bin, riddled with maggots.For every “perfect” pup that finds a loving home, many more are systematically destroyed. So horrendous has this market become, even the man who created the first ever labradoodle wishes he had never done it.Wally Conron successfully mated a labrador with a poodle in late 1980s to create Sultan for the Royal Guide Dog Association of Australia. He was motivated by a blind woman‘s desire for a guide dog that would not shed hair because her husband was allergic to it.But 30 years on Wally, now 90, says he regrets his experiment because it opened a “Pandora’s box”.Like drug trafficking, the designer dog world is predominantly run by organised criminals, whose only concern is making a profit.In 2012, the UK relaxed its border controls for travelling with pets. This opened the floodgates for trafficking in and out of the country.Dogs are mainly smuggled into the UK from Ireland, Ukraine and Hungry, flouting laws saying they must be at least 15 weeks old, microchipped, vaccinated against rabies, treated for tapeworm and have a pet passport.Organised gangs will also steal pedigree pets from their owners and take them to a breeding farm. Prices start at £500 and can rise to £3,000 depending on what you order.“Custom-made” and “allergy-free” dogs like Sultan can fetch even higher price tags.Along with the cockapoo, popular hybrid breeds include puggle , labradoodle , sprocker , Minnie Jack  and maltipoo .While dogs are the main focus of the designer pet industry, there are also kitten mills. The twisty cat or “squitten” is a cat bred specically for the deformity of stunted forelegs, so it looks like a cross between a cat and a squirrel.Fuelled by social media — Instagram is full of accounts for designer dogs — the appetite for hybrids seems never-ending. To feed this desire, organised criminals play God, creating Frankendogs — while destroying those who do not make the grade.Unlicensed and unregistered, they are free to treat the animals any way they like.Last year I was part of a team that raided a large puppy farm in Hawaiian Gardens, a city in Los Angeles County, which is where we discovered the dead cockapoo with the sign around its neck.We were alerted to the farm after receiving calls from people who bought puppies there that became seriously ill or died within days. The operation had no permits for boarding, breeding or selling.Our investigation revealed puppies who were about two weeks old, with designer breeds including miniature pinscher, Lhasa apso, dachshund, Maltese, poodle, Korean Jindo and English bulldog — all in ill health and kept in appalling conditions.In the breeding area, there were dogs with ulcerated eyes who were lethargic and unresponsive. Ears and tails cut off and tossed in bin. Wire cages were stacked and crammed with animals.The odours from the birthing secretions, dead puppies, filth, ammonia, faeces and mucus were awful. The puppies that were still alive were silent. We seized 367 dogs in total.The owners were banned from running any animal-related business and had to pay a fine of £65,000. Not long after, we raided another pet shop in Lynwood, also in Los Angeles County.We were met with another horric scene: Animals left to die in a bin behind the store, others covered in faeces, suffering from a catalogue of health problemsThere was a bloody newspaper over a table and syringes and sedatives in a bin. Some dogs’ ears and tails had been cut off and were crying in pain, their severed ears tossed into a bin.The investigation later revealed that when the store owner no longer wanted the animals — usually because they had medical issues or were no longer puppies — he suffocated them, beat them or threw them against the wall.The owner was convicted on multiple charges of animal cruelty and received six years in prison. These cases may have been in America but they are typical of the cruelty and neglect designer dogs can suffer all over the world in the push for profit.Animals like the ones found in these case frequently have ongoing medical problems for the rest of their lives. Sadly, the puppies were likely born ill, from overbred and malnourished mothers, and survived stressful transport to the pet shop only to be mistreated.They were born in squalor, transported in pain and then left in wretched conditions waiting to be bought. At only weeks old, they would have known no relief, no care and no peace.Our investigation has not been without its dficulties. While we have rescued tens of thousands of dogs from horric puppy farms and pet shops, we have received a backlash from some of the breeders.Sometimes they will break into our animal shelters and try to steal the seized dogs back. Other times they will throw rocks at our windows or send us threatening emails. But nothing is going to stop us from getting the message out there.I hope that by shining a light on this dark world, people will stop buying crossbreeds. And in turn this will stop the maltreatment and violence associated with the creation of designer dogs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: photo schoolboy carrying pensioner shopping
story: The unnamed boy was on his way home from school when the photo was snapped of him doing the selfless act.Emma Cope, from Kingstanding, West Midlands saw the little lad approach to help the elderly man using a crutch.Despite wearing a heavy backpack of his own, the boy volunteered to carry the large shopping bag.The 28-year-old was so moved by the heartwarming moment that she snapped the image and shared it on Facebook to show the boy’s actions.Emma also praised the boy’s parents in her post saying they “should be proud” for bringing up a “polite and caring lad”.Emma told Mail Online: “I couldnt believe it. I just had to take a photo.“The parents of this young man should be so proud as you have obviously brought up a polite and caring young lad.”The image shows the pair walking down the pavement and Emma adds the boy even walked slowly to keep pace with the pensioner.Emmas Facebook post read: “As I was getting out my car today In kingstanding, I heard this little boy say to this old man, can I help you carry your bag, to the mans delight he said oh yes please.. the old man walked slow and the little boy walked beside him and carried his bag!!“The parents of this young man should be so proud as you have obviously brought up a polite and caring young lad! title: raab interview brexit irish border
story: Brussels proposals for a customs border between Britain and Northern Ireland were rejected by Theresa May — sparking the current impasse.But Mr Raab says that while some in the EU Commission see it as a genuine solution to keep the Irish border open, others are “using it for political purposes”.He told The Sun: “If you walk around the corridors in Brussels, you hear all sorts of mutterings about how the UK must be ­penalised for leaving the EU, and the politicisation of Northern ­Ireland is part of that.“There are some out there in the Commission who see it as a lever beyond the substantive issue.There is no doubt there is a substantive issue about how we avoid a  to the hard border, but it has been magnied by those seeking to rely on it for political ends.”The accusations risk infuriating Brussels and further increasing tensions over the stalled talks.In his most outspoken interview since becoming Brexit Secretary — and marking the start of the Tories’ annual conference in Birmingham tomorrow — Mr Raab also:Mr Raab insisted opposite number in Brussels, Michel Barnier, is not one of those abusing the Irish border issue to punish Britain.Instead, he described him as a “decent, professional interlocutor with a good team around him”, adding: “I think they want a deal.”But he said of other senior figures in the Commission: “There is no doubt that it is being used for political purposes.”Cabinet members are pointing the finger at Commission Secretary-General Martin Selmayr.Top Tories think the German secretly wants the reunication of Ireland as a very public pitfall of Brexit.Mr Raab also revealed he is willing to listen to the EU  their reply to Mrs May’s ultimatum is not based on her Chequers’ plan.Asked  that included a fresh proposal for the sort of free trade agreement championed by Brexiteers, he added: “I will look at anything that they send back because this is a negotiation.“We aren’t pretending there aren’t alternative proposals that we would look at. In negotiations you do that.“But we need credible responses for the proposals we have set out or credible alternatives, and we haven’t seen them yet.”Saturday marks the six-month countdown to Brexit on March 29. But Mr Raab — the 44-year-old former Foreign Office lawyer — made it clear there can be no extension to talks past the summit planned for November 18.He said any delay, even to December, would leave it “extremely dficult” for either side to pass it through parliament.The Brexit Secretary added: “Otherwise we will end up with, in some ways what might be the worst case, which is a deal but without the time to implement it.”Despite the ticking clock, he admitted Brussels is yet to respond to Mrs May’s demand for movement from the EU.He said: “The ball is in their court.You wouldn’t expect to unblock some of those bigger sticking points around Northern Ireland and the Economic Partnership by now.”Warning that Britain won’t be reduced to begging, he added: “We are not some minnow. We are one of the biggest EU economies, one of the biggest economies in the world.“We are not going to get on our hands and knees and crawl back cap in hand for this deal.We are going to extend the arm of friendship, and see  it is reciprocated.”And in a rallying call to unite a split Tory Party, he said: “When we have got a deal negotiated with the EU and the option of No Deal, I think it will focus minds and I am confident that colleagues will put some of those dferences behind them and we will unite around a common position.”BRUSSELS has threatened to slap tough border limits on Brits  Theresa May’s post-EU immigration plans go ahead.Brexit negotiator Guy Verhofstadt, pictured below, warned of a tit-for-tat battle in a letter ahead of the Tory party conference.The PM will unveil plans to end priority job access for EU nationals and focus on those with in-demand skills.Mr Verhofstadt said the bloc will not sign a deal discriminating on nationality or type of job. It means emigrating Brits would face controls like EU citizens in the UK.GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may tory members sacked before election
story: It comes as a second survey found that 60 per cent of global investors dont have faith in her ability to deliver a Brexit deal by the November deadline.The analysis piles pressure on the beleaguered Prime Minister on the eve of the Tory conference in Birmingham.May is facing a huge Tory revolt after her Brexit blueprint was laughed out of the room by EU leaders in Salzburg.Conservative website ConHome found that 80 per cent of activists want her binned by the next election - with 35 thinking she should quit right now.The remaining 45 per cent want her axed before the next scheduled General Election in 2022.A Reuters poll meanwhile found that 60 per cent of business figures do not expect a trading agreement between Britain and the EU to be struck by the November.Mrs May is facing strong internal opposition from a large number of Conservative MPs.This reduces her room of manoeuvre , and we see a serious risk of early elections in the UK.On Friday Brexiteers praised Boris Johnson after he called on the PM to prove she has the guts for Brexit - by ripping up her Chequers plan.In a staggering eve of party conference blast, the ex-Foreign Secretary said the current backstop arrangement over Ireland should be axed.He called on No.10 to pursue a SuperCanada free trade deal with Brussels to fulfil the instruction of the Brexit vote in the 2016 Referendum.

title: gazza catches scuba diver fishing
story: The ex-England ace, 51, said his hook got stuck in the frogman’s neck while angling in the sea.Gazza, below, had been fishing off some rocks when he got a bite.He said: “The rod was double bent.I had it for about half an hour and I was like, this must be an unbelievable one.“All of a sudden a guy come up, scuba er, I’d caught him in the neck.“He was like, ‘Alright Gazza help us’.Sorry mate, I’ll just cut the line.Bang.I cut the line and went, ‘Go fish somewhere else’.I caught a scuba er.It was the biggest one I caught — I think.”Gazza, who took up fishing as a teenager, made the confession in an interview with the Angling Times.He previously said footie pal David Seaman saved him after he fell in a river having downed sleeping pills and Bacardi Breezers.Last week fans asked for refunds after saying Gazza arrived at a Gateshead event looking worse for wear.He denied he was drunk.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: photograph panther cumbria 15 years
story: Roy, 73, first spotted what he thought was a big cat while out walking his dog at night.He set up an infra-red motion-detecting camera and was amazed two days later when it captured this image.Cumbria Police have had more than 40 sights of a large cat in the south Lakes area in the last 15 years.Roy said: Everyone around here is aware of the stories of sightings of big cats and in all honesty I was a bit sceptical. But not anymore.It was unmistakably a big cat, it was enormous. It was around four feet long and it had a long curved tail which was around 18 inches long.There was no mistaking it for anything else, it was caught right in the beam of my torch and it was the eyes I saw first, they were bright green and around the size of an old penny.I was a bit apprehensive because it was quite a short distance away from me, only about 30 to 40 yards but from that distance I could tell it wasnt a dog or a domestic cat.I called out for Judith, my we, but she had gone back into the house so she didnt see it. He rigged up the camera near his home in Gatebeck, near Kendal, on September 11 and only had to wait two days before this photo was taken.Roy added: When I saw the picture it came as no shock to me because I knew what I had seen - I wasnt drunk and Ive no reason to make up a thing like that.What the image does achieve is to confirm its size. The water trough in the picture is six feet long so taking perspective into account the cat must be about 3ft 9in long. This is just the latest potential sighting in the local area.An estate agent friend of Roys reported seeing a big cat on his driveway as she was driving past on her way home.And during the cold snap earlier this year his son-in-law took a video showing giant paw prints the size of a mans gloved hand. Roy believes the cat lives in the vast expanse of wild countryside that borders the M6 through south Cumbria and feeds on rabbits.Since 2003 there have been reports of a large black cat in the same area with numerous sightings at Kendal, Sizergh, Sedbergh, Brigsteer and Witherslack.Last Stuart Wild and his we Liz were enjoying a stroll in the Lake District when they came across a similar creature near the hamlet of Little Langdale.Liz, 54, from Worcester, said at the time: There were some sheep in the field and one of my friends said: Look at that dog.But it was very feline and very, very big. You know how a cat stalks? It was like that. It was jet black and walking slowly. In March 2016 holidaying midwe Claire Greensmith spotted a “big, black panther-like creature” while hiking at a Colwith Force near Ambleside, In March 2015 a Freedom of Information request revealed that Cumbria Police had received 40 big cat sightings since 2003.Danny Bamping, from the British Big Cat Society, was doubtful that Roys photo was of a big cat.He said: The picture clearly shows a domestic cat.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: james forsyth no home comforts to ease the brexit bind
story: In the bars and on the fringe, vigorous argument will rage about what the best Brexit option is for Britain.Cabinet ministers will whisper in corridors about what the Government should do next. Boris Johnson will draw a big crowd for his “Chuck Chequers” rally.But there is a bigger danger waiting in the wings for the Tories: They simply don’t have a domestic agenda big enough for the moment.Labour has, over the past few days, set out its vision for Britain. It is, in places, scary. But give Jeremy Corbyn and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell this, it is undoubtedly clear and bold. As one Cabinet minister says, half admiringly:  “They’re hungry.”The Tories need to show  they have a better plan, one that will deal with people’s concerns— and they don’t have any time to waste. As one minister warns: “I’m just really terried. People don’t realise what a big deal this is.”The Tory Party’s problem is that it isn’t giving the country a vision of where it wants to take it. One former party leader has taken to lamenting that the Tories have “lost the narrative”.At conference last year, Theresa May declared that it was her mission to solve the housing crisis, to restore the British dream of home ownership for the many.But in the past 12 months, the Government has made far too little progress on this. Yes, some sensible steps have been taken. But the policies that will really solve this crisis, proper planning reform and a massive, Government-led housebuilding programme, haven’t happened.The result of all this: Jeremy Corbyn gets closer to power. As this newspaper revealed yesterday, Labour is now ahead in the seats that decide general elections thanks to its massive lead among renters.The likelihood of someone in their late twenties or early thirties on an average salary owning their own home has halved in the past 20 years.This is an electoral time bomb for the Tories. They can’t expect those without capital, or any prospect of getting it, to be capitalists.By the time of the next election, the Tories need to show people that their lives are getting better AND explain the damage  Corbyn would do to the country.One minister points the finger of blame at Number 10 for the Tory predicament. “A fish rots from the head down,” he tells me. But the Cabinet can’t escape its share of the blame, either.With a few exceptions, min­isters aren’t doing enough to take on Labour’s arguments. As one former Secretary of State fumed to me during Labour conference: “It’s outrageous. Where are the Cabinet?”If the Tories get Brexit wrong, it could cost them the next election. But even  they get a decent deal, it won’t guarantee them victory. For the public will vote on domestic issues — whether the housing crisis is solved, the state of the health service and what is going on with schools.Corbyn has simple answers to all these questions: They might be wrong, but they are answers. The Tories now need to show the country  they have answers too.AT last, some positivity and optimism about this country’s post-Brexit future from the Government.I can reveal  it is planning a major new festival celebrating the UK for 2022. The aim is for this festival to tell the world a story about Britain as we leave the EU and take charge of our own future. It is meant to coincide with the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee and the Commonwealth Games, which will be held in Birmingham that year.Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright,  who is pushing this idea in Whitehall, has told colleagues  it will be: “Future-facing, telling a story about the UK’s unique strengths, particularly as a place to invest, as we forge a new future outside the European Union.”If the Government gets it right, this festival could be a great statement about the open, dynamic country that Britain is going to be after Brexit. It should emphasise how this country is going out into the world after leaving the EU, not pulling up the drawbridge.The aim should be to put on something that stands comparison with the great post-war Festival of Britain in 1951 or even the Great Exhibition of 1851, which showcased Victorian Britain’s global reach and technological edge.One Secretary of State, who is backing the idea, tells me: “People just want something really positive.”But cynics might note that there is an advantage for the Tories in a feel-good festival in an election year.But I understand he will  have a harsh message for the Westminster politicians in attendance. He will  tell them to stop bickering and positioning and get on with delivering for the country.Mr Street will say that outside the Westminster bubble, the public just want politicians to get on with things, rather than constantly jostling for position.What makes his  speech so interesting is that he is a Downing Street favourite. Indeed, I understand  some of those close to Theresa May are pushing for a similar tone in her speech.They believe  her post-Salzburg speech went down so well with the public not just because she was standing up to the EU but because she was taking charge and being that “bloody dficult woman”. They think she should use her speech to tell members  they won’t get everything  they want from the Brexit talks, but that she will get the best deal for Britain.Others, though, are wary of this approach. One Cabinet minister cautions that after last year, May should play it safe as “you can’t have two bad years  in a row”.THE Government has rightly guaranteed that the three million EU citizens living in Britain will be able to stay in the event of no deal.This is sensible. These citizens contribute a lot to this country, and help keep our economy and our public services moving.But it is also right that the Government is now discussing what the rules will be for deporting EU citizens who commit crimes after Brexit in a no-deal scenario.The details have not yet been decided and, as one government source puts it: “No one wants people deported for getting a parking ticket.”But it is right that those who are convicted of a signicant offence are removed.• SPOT the leadership bid will be one of the games  the Tories play in Birmingham.Any Cabinet minister who starts talking about their childhood will be accused of planning a run for the top job.  This leaves ministers walking a tightrope as they prepare their speeches. Some are dealing with this challenge by handing their time  to others.Penny Mordaunt, the Aid Secretary, is simply introducing a series of “British heroes” who do development work.But one of those involved in conference planning suspects that even this is about leadership as Mordaunt “doesn’t want to spend 45 minutes defending the aid budget to a hall of Tory activists”.James Forsyth is political editor of The Spectator.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather britain coldest temperatures
story: It will be much cooler today and the rest of the weekend through to Monday as the mercury will drop to just 1C overnight.Mist patches and frost are likely to form in river valleys in the South, according to the Met Office.Met Office spokesman Stephen Keats said: “There will be a dip in temperatures for the next couple of days.“During the day it will top 17C in the South. But on Monday we can expect temperatures to dip to 14C or 15C.“The plunge is from cooler north westerly winds.”Temperatures will drop even more overnight on Sunday as some parts of the country will drop to -1C and -2C, which is colder that Iceland’s average forecast of 4C.Mr Keats said: “Sunday morning will see temperatures of -1C and -2C and that is mostly in Southern counties.”During the day temperatures will top 16C and on Monday some parts of the country will see an average of 14C.Met Office spokeswoman Nicola Maxey told The Mirror: “It is going to turn colder towards the weekend with a northerly flow of Arctic air bringing temperatures down compared to earlier in the week.“Overnight into Saturday we could see more widespread frosts with temperatures widely dropping, anywhere in the country could see a frost.She added: “There will be blustery showers around on Saturday and along northern coasts there will be the risk of gales.Simon Partridge, a Met Office meteorologist said: “There will be localised frost first thing in the morning but it will be dry, fine and sunny in most places.“There’ll be rain in north west Scotland which will move south but nothing too heavy.“It will feel breezier with temperatures hitting 18C.”It will get colder still on Sunday as maximum temperatures drop to between 15-16C.The Met Office spokesman said: “It will be a cloudy day for most as a band of cloud moves south.“They’ll be a scattering of showers in the north east but nothing too signicant as the rain continues to move south from Scotland.“For most of the country it will be sunny and chilly as temperatures reach 15-16C.”“Mostly it will be a dry weekend with temperatures of 18C at the average for this time of year.“The tops of the Scottish mountains will get a dusting of snow title: el chapo lieutenant damaso lopez convicted cartel
story: Evil Dámaso López - who sparked a wave of gangland violence in his bloodthirsty bid to take over the Sinaloa cartel - yesterday plead guilty to smuggling cocaine into the US.He now faces a potential le sentence in a high-security American jail.Known as El Licenciado - or the college graduate - Lopez was arrested in Mexico City in May 2017 after a huge CIA manhunt tracked him down to a dingy apartment.In July 2015 he reportedly helped cartel leader Joaquin El Chapo Guzman break out of jail.The plot involved cocaine baron escaping by riding a motorbike through a mile-long tunnel under his cell shower.Guzman has been held in solitary confinement in New York since being extradited to the United States on January 19.Last year Lopezs son - El Chapos godson - handed himself over to US cops after a failed bid to take over the cartel himself.Damaso Lopez Serrano bragged on social media about a le of luxury showing off pictures of beautul women, weapons and exotic animals.But it is believed that his dad fell out with Guzman’s children after El Chapo was arrested in 2016 which led to a split in the Sinaloa Cartel.After Licenciado was arrested in Mexico City in May it was believed his son would take control in Culiacan, a city in Sinaloa state.But the cartel ended up being lead by El Mayo - one of the criminal gang’s original founders.

title: pm world cup bid
story: The PM promised to put Government money behind the fledgling attempt to bring world football home again for the first time in 66 years.But the move lines her up in a head to head clash with Argentina, who are the current favourites with a joint bid alongside Uruguay and Paraguay.The FA has launched a study to probe a potential bid next year, along with football officials in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and Ireland.Ahead of the start of the Tory party conference in Birmingham, the PM seized on the “excitement” of the last World Cup.Mrs May said: “Following the excitement of this Summer’s World Cup, the English FA are working together with the FAs of Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and Ireland to explore whether there could be a joint bid to host the 2030 World Cup.“The decision on whether to bid is, of course, for the football associations to make.But  they decide to go forward, they can count on this government’s full support.”London and Glasgow will already host eleven games in the UEFA European Championship competition in 2020, with Wembley stadium hosting both the semi-final and final events.England last hosted the World Cup in 1966, the only time the team has lted the prestigious trophy.The next competition will be held in 2022 in Qatar and America and Mexico will jointly host the 2026 event.The Government believes it is time that the UK hosted the event again, as many other nations have won the bid to do so on more than one occasion since England last had the chance.The UK hosted the London 2012 Olympic Games, the 2013 Rugby World Cup and the
