title: theresa may prime minister age tuition fees salary birthday
story: Here is all you need to know about the Conservative leader who entered Number 10 unopposed but could never have predicted the turbulent term ahead of her.Theresa May became Prime Minister in July 2016 after she won the Conservative Party leadership election.This followed David Camerons resignation after losing the EU referendum.May, who has been a Tory MP since 1997, claimed she could bring strong and stable leadership following the Brexit vote - though she faced competition from Michael Gove and Andrea Leadsom.By July it was down to May and Leadsom before the latter officially withdrew from the race.As the sole remaining candidate, May was formally declared the Leader of the Conservative Leader on July 11, 2016 - this meant she became Prime Minister without having been elected.She was appointed PM by the Queen the next day.Theresa May has been the MP for Maidenhead since 1997.She was elected with 25,344 votes , almost double the total of second-placed Andrew Terence Ketteringham of the Liberal Democrats, who took 13,363 votes .In 2015 May held her seat with a 29,059 majority, and in 2017 she had a 26,457 majority over Labour’s Pat McDonald.In a surprise result, May was left scrambling to keep the Conservatives in power after Labour made signicant gains across the country.Despite the Tories topping 42 per cent of the vote share for the first time since 1987, they were mathematically unable to get a majority of MPs.The PM has now been left to oversee a weakened, minority government which has to rely on the support of the Democratic Unionist Party .The scenario makes a mockery of her “strong and stable” slogan she used throughout the campaign to win a larger mandate.May supported the UK remaining in the EU during the referendum campaign but was not a prominent campaigner.However during the conference outside Downing Street, May blasted rival parties for trying to derail the Government’s Brexit plans.She said the General Election was a chance to show unity, adding: “The country is coming together, but Westminster is not.”She has told the Cabinet that her Chequers plan for a Brexit deal will work as some EU leaders are beginning to crack.Dferences are finally emerging among the 27 other leaders who have been unied until now, the PM told her top table on Monday as she implored them to “hold our nerve”.And she believes the UK can exploit them to win goods-only access to the single market.In a bid to cheer up her Cabinet during her update to them on last week’s disastrous Salzburg summit, the PM told them: “Some heads of government want to be more constructive than the commission”.The development came as senior hardline Tory Brexiteers also turned up the pressure on Mrs May to dump her Chequers plan.May was born in Eastbourne, Sussex on October 1 1956, which means she is 62 years old.She graduated from Oxford University with a geography degree in 1977.May has previously worked as a financial consultant and senior adviser in International Affairs before she turned her attention to politics.Her previous positions in Government include Home Secretary and Minister for Women and Equalities.In 2011, then Home Secretary May, revealed to the Daily Mail that she has Type 1 diabetes, a disease which carries risks of heart attacks and strokes.Speaking at the time, May said she carries a needle with her at all times and must inject herself with insulin at least twice a day.She said: It was a real shock and, yes, it took me a while  to come to terms with it.The diabetes doesn’t affect how I do the job or what I do. It’s just part of le... so it’s a case of head down and getting on with it.The Prime Minister is paid £150, 402 a year, which includes the basic salary for an MP – currently set at £74, 962.Since April 2016, the PM has been allowed a higher wage of £152, 532 but this cant be taken because the government has frozen the pay of Cabinet ministers until 2020.This means 100 BBC stars earn more than Theresa May.But being Prime Minister does have its perks - May gets a £130,000 a year plush pad at No 11 Downing Street and free use of lavish Chequers throughout the year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: peru two michaella mccollum picture twin boys instagram

story: NewsBrits spend more than five hours per year deciding where to eatResearch suggest Brits just cannot make up their minds about what kind of nosh they want before dining outShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGrant Bailey23:36, 28 SEP 2018NewsIndecisive Brits have trouble picking a place to eat, according to research "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHungry Brits spend the equivalent of more than five hours EVERY year deciding where to eat, it has emerged. Research also revealed millions of diners are shying away from trying new foods because they can’t decide what to go for. And although we describe ourselves a nation of foodies, with the average Brit dining out at least once a month, the results found six in 10 play their meal choices 'safe' by eating at the same places, time and time again. The research was conducted by Meerkat Meals, who created a unique ‘Restaurant Roulette’ tool to help diners decide what to eat by picking from a list of cuisines. Julie Daniels of Compare the Market said: “Everyone loves dining out, and with such a wide selection of restaurants and cuisines so easily accessible, we’re a nation spoilt for choice. “However, the seemingly-simple question of 'What do you want to eat?’ can often become an excruciating conversation, and this in turn is meaning many are finding the whole experience dficult.'' The study also found a common barrier to trying new eateries is the size of the dining group, with nearly half of those polled saying it's harder to pick a restaurant when eating out with four or more people.  It also emerged choosing where to eat in a group takes on average 25 minutes, which mounts up to over five hours over a year. The pressure of deciding where to eat amongst a group can even take the fun out of the evening, with almost half of diners saying choosing a restaurant that everyone likes takes the fun out of the experience. The research also found diners much prefer to eat out when the choice of restaurant is taken out of their own hands. More than one third agreed it was much easier when somebody else chose the dining destination. And when it comes to the culinary desires of the nation, Caribbean came out as the cuisine people would most like to try, with a fth of diners saying it was on top of their “to-try” list. title: brett kavanaugh senators allow vote
story: NewsBrett Kavanaugh: Senators ALLOW vote on controversial judge's appointment - but not before FBI investigationDonald Trump has ordered an FBI investigation into sex assault allegations against Brett Kavanaugh following an extraordinary intervention by Senator Jeff FlakeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNeil MurphyRichard Cowan19:06, 28 SEP 2018Updated22:57, 28 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/republican-led-committee-approves-nomination-13327591,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Republican-led committee has voted to allow Brett Kavanaugh take his seat on the U.S. Supreme Court, paving the way for a full Senate vote on the issue.  In a dramatic turn of events, Senator Jeff Flake said he would vote for Kavanaugh's nomination, but wanted a one-week delay so a 'limited' FBI investigation could take place. Now Donald Trump has ordered the FBI to respond over fears his party could lose the crucial Senate floor vote. I've ordered the FBI to conduct a supplemental investigation to update Judge Kavanaugh's file. As the Senate has requested, this update must be limited in scope and completed in less than one week, Trump said in a statement. Eleven Republicans voted to accept Kavanagh's nomination, with 10 Democrats voting in objection, further exposing deep political isions on Capitol Hill. Senators held proceedings up for 20 minutes as they were involved in last-minute wrangling over their decision. The move follows a jarring and emotional hearing against the Trump nominee who was accused of sexually assaulting university professor Christine Blasey Ford in 1982, when she was 15-years-old. Earlier, angry Democrats walked out as the Senate Judiciary Committee in protest as Republicans pushed forward with the vote. What a railroad job, Democratic Senator Mazie Hirono said.  Republican Senator Chuck Grassley, the chairman of the committee, praised Kavanaugh as he pressed forward with the vote. The alleged behavior is inconsistent with everything else we know about him, Grassley said of Kavanaugh. It was only fair that his accuser had the burden of proof. In my opinion, this wasn't met, Grassley added. The timing of the panel's session gave committee members little time to review Thursday's extraordinary testimony from Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford. Kavanaugh forcefully denied the accusations and accused Democrats of a calculated and orchestrated political hit.  Senator Dianne Feinstein, the senior Democrat on the committee, criticized Kavanaugh's remarks, saying they were unseemly for a judicial nominee. This was someone who was aggressive and belligerent. I have never seen someone who wants to be elevated to the highest court in the country behave in that manner. In stark contrast, the person who testied yesterday and demonstrated a balanced temperament was Dr. Ford. She gave powerful testimony about her experience of being physically and sexually assaulted by Brett Kavanaugh, Feinstein said. Brett Kavanaugh broke down in tears during the dramatic hearing in which he categorically denied sexual assault allegations made against him. University professor Christine Blasey Ford told the hearing she was 100 percent certain Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her 36 years ago. But calling himself a victim of grotesque and obvious character assassination, Kavanaugh said he unequivocally and categorically denied Ford's allegation.  He labelled other accusations of sexual misconduct also from the 1980s made by two additional women who did not appear before the panel as vicious and false. Ms Ford told the hearing she feared he would rape and accidentally kill her. But Kavanaugh insisted: I have never done this, to her or to anyone. A committee vote to approve Kavanaugh which pave the way for a final debate and vote on the Senate floor in the coming days.  Flake, who had raised concerns about the allegations, said on Friday morning he would vote in favor of the nomination. Flake said in a statement that while Ford's testimony was compelling, Kavanaugh gave a persuasive response.  Soon after Flake made his announcement, he was angrily confronted by protesters in an elevator while on his way to the committee meeting. If the nomination reaches the full Senate, where Trump's fellow Republicans hold a slim 51-49 majority, the votes of two other so-far undecided Republican moderates could be crucial: Lisa Murkowski and Susan Collins. Democrats have urged a delay to allow for an FBI investigation, a move backed late Thursday by the American Bar Association, which had earlier endorsed his nomination. Why are they shutting it down? I believe it's because they are trying to hide something, Senator Amy Klobuchar, a Democrat on the committee, told NBC's Today program on Friday. Kavanaugh could be the deciding vote on several contentious cases  he is confirmed, with disputes involving abortion, immigration, gay rights, voting rights and transgender troops possibly heading to the court soon. What happens next?  The Senate floor was expected to vote withing days of Kavanaugh's nomination but a dramatic intervention by Senator Jeff Flake has halted planned proceedings for now. Democrats had originally asked for an FBI probe into Blasey Ford's allegations but Republican lawmakers strongly rejected their proposals before the hearing. At news conference with Chile's President, Donald Trump told gathered White House reporters that he had been moved by Blasey Ford's testimony. I thought her testimony was very compelling, and she looks like a very fine woman, Trump said. He also said moderate Senators, Lisa Murkowski and Susan Collins, must 'do what they think is right' when they cast their crucial votes.

title: brian reade never before serious
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: Never before have serious events given us such belly laughsWhen Trump's UN speech was met with chortles, titters and giggles, we got the final confirmation that everything has gone seriously Pete TongShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrian Reade23:51, 28 SEP 2018NewsopinionTrump is performing the rib-tickling, cringe-inducing stand-up set the world never asked for "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSomeone once said that laughter is the sun that drives winter from your face. If so, it might explain why we’ve still got the garden furniture out as we head into October. Not because of what’s in the sky but because it’s hard to recall a time when the so-called serious, grown-up events that are meant to shape the world have drawn so many belly laughs. Look at the entire United Nations General Assembly rolling around in stitches like Martian robots on the old Smash advert this week as the world’s most powerful man addressed them. When Donald Trump announced “my administration has accomplished more than almost any administration in the history of this country”, he was drowned out with guffaws. This has literally never happened in this very sombre organisation’s 73-year history. Was it his hair, the ease with which fiction leaves his puckered lips, or his rare show of modesty by using the word “almost”? Who knows.  But those delegates were smirking again when Trump accused the Chinese of interfering in US elections without mentioning the Russians, whose foreign minister stared at his phone, struggling to keep a straight face. Mind you, the rest of the world has been struggling to do the same ever since Vladimir Putin claimed the two hitmen he’d sent to Salisbury to take out Sergei Skripal were simply Songs of Praise fans who adored the cathedral so much they saved all their rubles to come over and gaze at its spire. Which was funny. But now it’s been revealed that one of those hitmen was an elite special forces colonel in Russian &shyintelligence who was awarded the country’s top military honour, it gets even funnier. How less elite can a special forces spook be than one who leaves his grinning mug plastered all over CCTV street cameras? I know, one who can’t bump off a pensioner whose greatest pleasure appears to be sitting in pubs and restaurants supping lager. Not that us Brits aren’t coming up with the laughs. UKIP MEP Lord Dartmouth has quit the party because it’s become too racist. Eh? That’s like quitting Mumsnet because all the women keep banging on about babies. Why else did he join?  Then, after Jeremy Corbyn’s &shyconference speech, there were the right-wing papers lampooning him in one breath as an eccentric Catweazle figure with loony policies, then in the next warning the Tories they need to take him seriously as a disillusioned Middle England could just buy them. Which brings us to Birmingham turning into Comedy Central next week when loose-dentured geriatrics spill their colostomy bags all over the Tory conference hall as their G-spots take direct hits from misty-eyed Brexiters fantasising about Victorian maids cycling through villages where everything, from the cricket flannels to the faces, are white. Remember last year when Theresa May’s cough-laden speech was so boring even the letters behind her dropped off?

The weather will do a U-turn after this week's warm sunshine, light winds and pleasant temperatures that hovered in the teens. Instead, today could mark the last of the sun and the start of weeks of chillier weather and unsettled conditions that could continue throughout October. The Met Office is forecasting that temperatures will fall close to or a little below normal with some weather experts suggesting it could reach a low as -2 in Scotland while Wales and the north of England will see single digit figures. Today will not only bring frosts and freezing frogs to kick off the weekend, but the north of the country could also be battered by blustery showers and gale force winds.  The Met Office predicts today will be another fine day for England and Wales with long sunny spells, but it will be cloudier and windy elsewhere, with rain moving southeastwards across Scotland and reaching Northern Ireland by evening. Met Office spokeswoman Nicola Maxey added: “It is going to turn colder towards the weekend with a northerly flow of Arctic air bringing temperatures down compared to earlier in the week. “Overnight into Saturday we could see more widespread frosts with temperatures widely dropping, anywhere in the country could see a frost. “It will stay cooler into Sunday and after some morning fog, there is the likelihood of sunny spells with daytime temperatures around the mid-teens again.  “There will be blustery showers around on Saturday and along northern coasts, there will be the risk of gales. “Across the southern half of the country there is more of a chance of seeing some sunshine, the risk of frosts will continue into the start of next week. “There may be some sleet or wet snow over high ground in the north on Sunday night.” According to the Met Office tomorrow will be drier, but we can expect to see rain once again by Tuesday. A forecast read: Showers in north and east Sunday, these wintry over Scottish mountains. Dry with sunny spells elsewhere. Largely fine Monday, but rain reaches the northwest later, and clears southeastwards during Tuesday.

Mum-of-four Kirsty said Harrison was looking forward to adding to his collection with the Lego card collectors' album from the supermarket in Ashford, Kent. When Kirsy's children ed home from school on September 25, they opened the packet and discovered the blade. She said: They brought over this Stanley blade to me which was still in the packet. I was angry, I have a one-year-old and  it had dropped onto the floor he could've easily eaten it - I was really annoyed. Kirsty, from Stanhope, Kent, stormed over to Sainsbury's to complain - and was given a &pound10 voucher. She added: You shouldn't have to check a pack of children's cards for blades.

title: unwelcome visitor asda trifle left
story: NewsAsda trle containing 'unwelcome visitor' leaves woman feeling like she wants to 'gargle with bleach'Julie Collier said she felt something hard and sharp in her mouth while eating the own-brand dessert and spat it outShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJenny KirkhamKate McMullin20:53, 28 SEP 2018Updated21:33, 28 SEP 2018NewsJulie Collier says she was horried after finding a cockroach in her Asda trle"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman was left feeling like she would like to gargle with bleach after she claims she found an unwelcome visitor in an Asda trle.  Julie Collier says she was horried and in a state of nausea after finding a cockroach in the own brand dessert. The 54-year-old, from Belle Vale, Liverpool, says she tasted something metallic, hard and sharp halfway through the trle and spat it out. It was then, she claims, that she saw the creature's legs.  Julie told the Liverpool Echo : Halfway through the trle I discovered an odd glass-like texture in my mouth and it tasted metalic.  I didn't bite down thankfully but spat it out into a tissue, that's when I saw the legs. I was left absolutely horried when I realised it was actually a cockroach. Julie said that the large insect was covered in jelly and cream when she threw it down on the counter in her kitchen.   Julie, who says she has a extreme fear of insects , said: After seeing it I'm in a state fluctuating between horror, nausea and feeling that I would like to gargle with bleach.  This has definitely put me off shopping at Asda, I'm already fussy about food and where I buy it from but this has traumatised me. It is gross. I don't even think I've ever seen a cockroach in this country. Pictures taken after Julie says she found the cockroach show it to be around the same size as a two pence coin, covered in raspberry jelly, with all six legs still intact. She had bought a two pack of trles at the Asda Superstore in Huyton as part of her weekly shop but says she is yet to receive a reply from the company after sending a complaint email to their customer service department.

title: married couple reveal invited another
story: NewsMarried couple reveal why they invited another woman to join their relationship nine years after weddingThe throuple have been together for 10 months and say they are in love, despite some of their family members' disapprovalShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRebecca DrewDanya BazaraaNews Reporter21:50, 28 SEP 2018Updated22:19, 28 SEP 2018NewsAshley , Mike  and Kristina  have spoken honestly about how their relationship works for them "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA married couple of nine years have revealed why they invited another woman to join their relationship. Self-employed sports analytic Mike, 40, and special education teacher Kristina Green, 34, had been married for eight years when they decided to look for a girlfriend. The couple from Pennsylvania, USA, met therapist Ashley Sweet, who was married at the time but openly dating other people, through mutual friends at a social event. And they have now officially been a throuple for 10 months - despite some of their family members not approving of their unconventional relationship and receiving looks of disdain when they are out and about. Ashley, 31, said: Polyamory is about being open to more. More love, more partners, more experiences.  Society is largely centred around monogamy, this idea that there is only one 'person' for you. But what  there's more than one? Why should we limit ourselves because of a social rule? Having more than one partner means I see the world through my gaze, his gaze, and hers. My understanding of the world and what it has to offer is vastly expanded by being open to loving and sharing with more than one amazing person. She added: Our relationship works through open and honest communication, respect and consideration for one another's feelings and thoughts, and a willingness to compromise for the best interests of all. For a polyamorous relationship, we have to work harder on those things, because there are more needs, wants, feelings, thoughts and input at any given time. We are also all unique and dferent, and so rather than having to consider one partner's needs and dferences, we consider two. Occasionally one of us is on one side and another is on the opposite side of the issue at hand, and the need for respect and compromise becomes more important.  The three instantly clicked and started to date on a casual basis before Mike and Kristina asked Ashley to officially form a triad as they had fallen in love with her. Ashley and her husband separated as of July this year for reasons unrelated to their polyamorous lestyle, with him always being supportive of her relationship with Mike and Kristina. Kristina, Mike and Ashley have three children between them who they raise together - aged 11, seven and seven. Ashley works a busy schedule that often means she is away from the family home, so feelings of jealousy sometimes arise over the time that they get to spend with each other. But the throuple have now found a way to navigate these emotions and work through them together so that everyone feels included. The triad view their relationship as a triangular shaped unit with each person benefiting inidually from their unique setup. For Kristina, being in a triad has given her a female and male partner and allowed her to explore herself more than she did when she was in a monogamous relationship. From Mike's perspective, the triad means he receives more of everything he did before, and Ashley receives balance in her love le.  It allows for additional avenues to share and explore the world with people I care about, said Mike. Being poly gives you a dferent perspective on the world in general. We don't view things through the normal society's spectrum. Ashley continued: We talk a lot and have developed a POT  where we all hold hands and agree to listen without judgement to one another. Having a 'safe space' where we take time to consider our needs and be mindful of being respectful allows us to communicate more openly and honestly. There are often feelings of jealousy, particularly around time spent together. Ashley says she works an unconventional schedule in therapy and so spends more time away from home when the family is together, and admits she can sometimes feel left out. She said: We joked once, months ago, that we should have a word to express when someone feels left out without having to share the vulnerable feelings, because feeling left out in our triad is complicated, as you feel both excluded and guilty for potentially taking time from your partners. So now we say 'orangutan', which is comical, but also allows us to share when something or some configuration leads to feelings of exclusion. When we disagree, we sometimes talk in our triad, and sometimes  the disagreement is between a pairing, the third partner will try to bring the other two together to hash out the feelings and needs.  Despite being madly in love with each other, the triad have received mixed reactions from their family members ` with only Ashley's parents supporting their arrangement and willing to learn more. My birth parents and family seem more accepting and have been willing to listen and get to know Ashley, said Kristina. My adopted mother is not very accepting at this time, but my siblings are very supportive. Mike said his brother is tolerant, his sister is accepting, but his other sister has not approved. He explained: My family more or less disapproves, and my mother has refused to meet her [Ashley]. Most of my family hates our relationship. Ashley said: My parents have been surprisingly open and accepting. My mother will ask questions and my dad is supportive  confused. My sisters are a little less embracing: apart from the youngest, my sisters have expressed confusion, disapproval and concern for the best interests of their children as well as mine. I would say that my oldest truly understands the dynamic we have. I explained the relationship in the context of consent, that just like you wouldn't date or touch someone without consent, having more than one partner is allowed as long as everyone consents. He's been adjusting to having to listen to more adults, but he loves everyone.

title: las vegas massacre brought together
story: News'Las Vegas massacre brought us together': Couple fell in love after helping each other survive night of horrorBryan Hopkins grabbed the hands of the two nearest strangers and ran for his le - little did he know one of them was his soulmate Nicole RuffinoShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrodie CooperJames Desborough21:19, 28 SEP 2018Updated21:20, 28 SEP 2018NewsNicole Ruffino and Bryan Hopkins fell in love the night they helped each other escape the Las Vegas mass shootings "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe instant Bryan Hopkins saw people in the Las Vegas concert crowd fall to the ground, he knew bullets, not firecrackers, were ripping through the air. Grabbing the hands of the nearest two strangers, Nicole Ruffino and her friend, he led them to take refuge inside a refrigerator truck backstage. And there, huddled together as more than 1,000 rounds from Stephen Paddock’s guns killed 58 people, Bryan kept Nicole safe – and fell in love. Now, days before the first anniversary of the worst mass shooting in modern US history, inseparable Bryan, 49, and Nicole, 25, reveal how they found each other while hiding from a killer. Bryan says: “October 1 will always stay with us because of that horric tragedy.  “But now this first anniversary is not just about remembering those that lost their lives, but celebrating how lucky I am to have met Nicole. “I remember telling Nicole that night I would always be there for her as words of support in that situation – but now those words have taken on new meaning. “It really was the key moment in my le. I held her hand and fell in love with her instantly.” Nicole took slightly longer to realise she had found love in the arms of the man who sheltered her. She says: “Bryan saved me that night, but in the next few months, I fell in love with a warm, caring, creative man, and I am so grateful.”  Bryan, a country music artist, was hailed a hero in the aftermath of the massacre. He and radiographer Nicole were strangers standing next to each other in the crowd at the Route 91 Harvest Festival when Paddock began firing from floor 32 of the Mandalay Bay hotel. Bryan took hold of Nicole and her friend Nicole Yorba and urged them to run. When they reached the backstage area, he led the women, and 30 others, into the catering fridge unit. Video shows Nicole cowering next to Bryan, who recorded a &shyfarewell message for his parents in case he did not survive.  Bryan tried to calm the panicking group for around five minutes, before deciding they needed to clear the whole target area. Peering out of the door during a break in the shots, he noticed a metal ramp leaning against a 10ft fence. He hurried the group up the ramp and together, against the echo of gunshots and in total darkness, they ran into open ground towards the safety of the Strip. Afterwards, Bryan and Nicole appeared in dozens of media interviews retelling their traumatic experience while holding hands. “Holding her hand felt like the most natural thing to do as we did interviews together,” says Bryan. “It was subconscious and, truthfully, I never wanted to let it go.”  Bryan, lead singer with his band Elvis Monroe, threw himself into supporting the #Vegasstrong movement by performing at numerous fundraising concerts. On October 13, the band played at the Mandalay Bay and things changed for ever. Nicole says: “I wanted to see Bryan, but I was anxious about heading back to that hotel where the tragedy happened. “He met me in the parking garage for reassurance and held my hand and walked me in. Later, as we watched the acts, he had his hand on my leg. Afterwards, he walked me back to the car, opened the door for me, smiled and gently leaned in to kiss me. “I was taken by surprise and naturally leaned in to him. It was pure impulse for both of us. I never saw it coming, but my instincts just knew it was right.”  The pair began casually, and secretly, dating. But then, in November, Nicole was struck down with viral meningitis. Bryan was by her side during her three weeks in intensive care while specialists battled to treat the brain infection and then helped her back to full health for another six weeks. But then Nicole had second thoughts about how fast and intense their relationship had grown. She says: “I was worried about the big age dference and getting too involved. I insisted we’d just be friends.” Bryan was devastated. He says: “I did tear up, but I held on to my belief that we could still make it.” Bryan was right. Because Nicole soon realised just how much she missed him.

title: cammy kerr calls on dundee to show dee fiant spirit
story: Cammy Kerr has called on everyone at Dundee to revive the Dee-fiant spirit to get out of the trouble they find themselves in at the bottom of the Premiership table.The 3-0 home defeat to Hibs last weekend leaves the Dark Blues still stuck on zero points after six league fixtures.A lelong fan of the club, Kerr, however, knows Dundee have got through tougher situations than this in their history.Though he admits they’ll need exactly the same “character” as the club showed to overcome a 25-point deduction in 2010  they are to get off the foot of the ision.He said: “As you see the games going and the points staying the same, it is dficult but that’s why you are a football player and have got to this stage and you need to deal with ups and downs and struggles along the way.“This club has had plenty of struggles in its time, it’s had points deductions and all sorts of things – it’s now about showing that character within the club that I believe no other club has.“We just have to find that within ourselves and push it on and make sure nothing stops us in this search for a victory.“We had a poor start a couple of years ago but we turned things around and that’s what I’m trying to get at.“It’s so dficult but being a Dundee fan and seeing things the way I have over the years, I know there is nothing that should allow this club to say no.“Everyone pulling together, the office staff, kitchen staff, the youth boys, everyone, just keep smiling, keep plugging away and it’s going to turn, I’m positive of that.”Honest as ever, Kerr admits this season just plainly hasn’t been good enough from Dundee.“If you let things get out of hand it’s like a disease that spreads,” he added.“It’s all confidence-related and, as the manager spoke about before, we just need a goal to get us in front.“However, at the same time,  we are going behind in games, we can show resilience that we don’t lie down but fight for every ball, every tackle, everything we have in us, we keep fighting to the end. We just seem to be falling short just now and it’s not good enough.“There’s nothing else for it, it’s the same old cliched stuff – you’ve just go to keep fighting away.“You need to be ready to go on the training field, pushing yourself to the max every day.“We have to put in the hard yards and that’s the only way it will turn.“I know the fans and everyone at the club is frustrated, they’re obviously used to seeing better times than this, but there is still time to get our season going.“That’s the only positive – there’s another game in a few days’ time, a massive game against Hamilton and we’ve got to go and make sure we get a victory.“I know, it’s easy saying that and the punters will be sick to the back teeth of people saying ‘next week, next week’ but it’s the only thing for it.”Hamilton against Dundee has been a grudge match over the past few years and last season at New Douglas Park was one of the stand-out moments for the Dark Blues as they came from behind to win the game in the 97th-minute through A-Jay Leitch-Smith.Kerr added: “Last season at Hamilton was amazing, an incredible finish to the game and that again was a resilient performance full of character within the group.“It’s dficult being positive after Saturday’s defeat and having no points from the first six games but we have to go there, knowing how hard it is down there, it’s an absolute dogfight.“They got a great result last week but it’s a game of football, 90 minutes, and  we get ourselves on top we can win the game on Saturday.”

title: coffee giant starbucks plans to open second drive thru in dundee
story: Coffee giant Starbucks could open a second drive-thru branch on Dundee’s ring road in the near future.The chain opened its first drive-thru at Wester Gourdie Industrial Estate earlier this year, and has now submitted a proposal for another.If approved, the branch would occupy land on Afton Way, close to the city’s Morrisons store.Representatives for Morrisons, which owns the entire site at Afton Way, say the planned shop would match the “signicant” growth of drive-thru coffee shops across the country.It would also serve a iety of people from passing motorists on the A90 through to nearby residents.The new proposal,  approved by Dundee city planners, would also create new jobs, and contribute to ongoing regeneration efforts in the North East.In a statement, representatives for Morrisons said: “The proposed small-scale drive- thru unit will form a complementary addition to the existing Morrisons store.“It will also generate a number of job opportunities for local people.”The application also hints at further development to come at Afton Way.Initial talk of an expansion on the site began as early as January 2013 – with other potential developments in future including a pub.Diagrams included with the Starbucks proposals detail a new, more convenient entrance to the site from the southbound A90 Forfar Road.However, this is likely to form part of a separate planning application in due course.And Morrisons also had a plan to mody and expand its petrol station approved in October last year.Starbucks’ latest move to build on Dundee’s ring road comes at a time of intense interest from developers on the Kingsway.Alongside the now-opened Starbucks drive-thru at Myrekirk, plans have also been approved for a retail complex on Kingsway East at Craigie.That development will boast a Lidl, a car dealership and a Costa Coffee drive-thru.Starbucks also has a sit-in coffee shop at the Overgate Centre.

title: csaba happy to be able to call on quality as dundee united prepare for ross county
story: Boss Csaba Laszlo will be pleased to be able to turn to his bench for support as his Dundee United side host Ross County at Tannadice.Csaba will welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold after he missed last Saturday’s 2-0 win over Falkirk due to him not being risked on the articial surface so soon after recovering from a knee injury.He will be joined in the matchday party by winger Billy King as a few other absentees fight back to contention.“With these players coming back it will create more competition and up the quality in training,” Csaba said.“Sam Stanton and Stewart Murdoch are back in training with the team, while Nicky Clark will need another week.“It is important to get these players back to speed.”On Fyvie, Csaba added: “It was a frustration to have a player that can’t play.“We also have to accept that he is a player who has been injured long-term.“It has not just been an easy injury that takes a little time to recover from.“Psychologically, you must also be ready for this kind of match.“As a manager, you have to accept it when a player says ‘This isn’t the best game for me, on the articial pitch’.“For that reason he didn’t play but he will be OK for the Ross County match.”One player Csaba has, sadly, ruled out for the forseeable future is Lewis Toshney.“He has been out for a year so it is not easy for him.“He is fighting to come back.“I am happy that he can train but I don’t think we can talk just now about the first team.”

title: designer says maggies penguin parade in dundee can inspire future artists
story: The success of charity art trails highlights the positive effect sculpture can play in bolstering civic pride, a University of Dundee academic has said.Janice Aitken, associate dean for public and community engagement at Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design, said that the success of campaigns like the city’s Maggie’s Penguin Parade would also help to inspire future generations of artists.Janice, who created the original design used for the cancer charity’s summer fundraiser, made the comments ahead of speaking at Dundee Arts Cafe this coming Tuesday.“It’s very important to celebrate a rich culture and heritage in any community,” she said.“Having a sense of fun and civic pride makes any city a more positive place to live.”Janice will speak about the benefits of public art and her association with the Penguin Parade, which saw 80 dferent sculptures put in place throughout Dundee over the summer.

title: dundee are currently the worst football team in the world
story: Dundee are currently the worst football team in the world, according to statistics.The pressure is mounting on manager Neil McCann after Saturday&#8217s 3-0 home defeat by Hibernian left his side with a record of six defeats in six Premiership games so far this season.And the beleaguered boss will be even more dismayed to discover that, according to one calculation, the Dark Blues are bottom of a world league.Football website whoscored, which takes data from 153 countries, ranks Dundee at the bottom of the international form guide.According to the site, only two other clubs in the world &#8211 Scottish Championship side Falkirk and Bulgarian outfit Septemvri Sofia &#8211 have lost six in a row.But Dundee&#8217s goal dference of -12 puts them at rock bottom.The Dark Blues&#8217 &#8216progress&#8217 in the table has been eagerly followed by Dundee United fans on Twitter.According to @callum1247, the clinching result was last night when Guingamp picked up a point away to Nimes in France&#8217s Ligue 1.Dundee fans have hit back at the inevitable jibes. Dougie Ferguson  posted: &#8220I’m desperate for a win Saturday , just to stop the banter from over the road.&#8221Type23 also took a swipe at United fans: &#8220That&#8217s ok though, you boys still top the league for being the most obsessed.&#8221Dundee&#8217s visit to Hamilton this Saturday is already considered a must-win, with the Tele reporting prior to the Hibernian loss that McCann had only another three games to save his job.Dundee boss Neil McCann has THREE GAMES to save his job" src="https:www.eveningtelegraph/fp/dundee-boss-neil-mccann-has-three-games-to-save-his-job/embed/#?secret=EerpgFUL67" data-secret="EerpgFUL67" width="600" height="338" title="&#8220Dundee boss Neil McCann has THREE GAMES to save his job&#8221 &#8212 Evening " frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"

title: dundee gaffer neil mccann hoping lengthy injury list eases for crunch hamilton clash
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is hoping his walking wounded recover in time for today’s vital Premiership game against Hamilton kicks off.The Dens gaffer is under pressure to arrest his side’s run of straight defeats – six in the league, seven in all competitions – as the Dark Blues head to Lanarkshire to take on Accies.Martin Canning’s men sit on six points and can move nine clear of their relegation rivals with a second win in two, after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren last week.Neil will have at least one addition to his options after winger Roarie Deacon declared himself available for action.After a y period out, caused by an injury to his ankle picked up in the last game of last season against Partick which required surgery, it’s likely the former Arsenal man will have to settle for a place on the bench.Last week’s 3-0 defeat to Hibs saw Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all limp off.Finnish striker Kallman’s problem was cramp and won’t keep him out today while Madianga and Miller’s injuries were muscle based and it remains to be seen how long they may be out for.The club are hopeful Josh Meekings will be back fit after a thigh injury picked up against Motherwell four weeks ago.He missed the defeat to Hibs, though, Neil may be tempted to stick with his two loan signings Andy Boyle and Ryan Inniss in any case.At the top end of the field, the Dens boss will be hoping targetman Sofien Moussa has recovered from his knock picked up before the loss to Hibs to give him another option in attack.Meanwhile, Kenny Miller will serve the final game of his two-match suspension today.

title: dundee msps rack up more than 3000 in edinburgh hotel expenses
story: Two Dundee-based MSPs have racked up more than a quarter of the total spend by Holyrood politicians on taxpayer-funded hotel dining in Edinburgh.The SNP’s Joe FitzPatrick claimed £2,001 on evening meals at Edinburgh lodgings in 2017/18, while Scottish Conservative Bill Bowman spent £1,197.Their combined bill makes up 27% of the £11,806 claimed by all 129 MSPs for hotel dinners, according to official figures published by the Scottish Parliament on Thursday.Politicians can be reimbursed for overnight stays in Edinburgh  they are based far enough away from Holyrood.Although MSPs are allowed to claim hotel evening meals as part of their accommodation provision, most do not.Mr Bowman, who has a portfolio of investments worth more than £600,000, became a North East MSP following the death of Alex Johnstone in December 2016.Mr FitzPatrick has been the Dundee West MSP since winning the seat from Labour in 2007.Neither politician is able to claim back rent for a property in Edinburgh, which is available for MSPs based further afield and would keep costs down.Holyrood sits Tuesday to Thursday during term time.A spokesman for the SNP MSP said: “Mr FitzPatrick’s previous role and commitments as minister for parliamentary business necessitated more frequent overnight stays in Edinburgh.”A party spokesman for Mr Bowman said: “We follow parliamentary rules on expenses.”

title: dundee music star be charlotte stars in african festival this weekend
story: Dundee pop star Be Charlotte is performing at Lake of Stars Malawi Arts Festival in Africa this weekend.Lake of Stars is one of the country’s most respected arts festivals, attracting performers and visitors from across the globe.Charlotte Brimner, also known as Be Charlotte, recently signed a major deal with Columbia/ Sony music and also performed at the 3D Festival in celebration of the opening of V&ampA Dundee.She is widely regarded as one of the most exciting prospects in Scottish contemporary music.Charlotte will share the stage with some of Scotland’s finest musicians and poets, including Michael Pedersen of Neu! Reekie! and Scottish Album of the Year Award nominee Kobi Onyame.Supported by Creative Scotland, the festival is celebrating its 15th anniversary by connecting artists from the Scottish music and poetry scenes with artists from Malawi.It runs until Sunday.&nbsp

title: dundees bid for big oil projects rejected because port is too shallow
story: Dundee’s bid to become a centre for large-scale oil and gas decommissioning projects was rejected because the approach to the port is “too shallow”.Despite owner Forth Ports investing £10 million to ensure the port was capable of handling large-scale projects,  Shetland was chosen this month as the best site to carry out large-scale oil and gas decommissioning.Consultants Ernst and Young decided Dundee was unsuitable after just the first of its three testing stages.Its full report is still to be published but energy minister Paul Wheelhouse revealed the reason for Dundee’s rejection in a response to a written parliamentary question by Conservative MSP Bill Bowman.He said the approach to the docks only has a depth of six metres, not the nine required, and with dredging work, the approach to Dales Voe in Shetland will be 24 metres deep.He said: “Although Dundee is suitable for a range of decommissioning works, because the approach depth was insufficient for those projects requiring a deep water port, it was therefore not assessed further than Stage one.”Stuart Wallace, chief operating officer of Forth Ports, which owns the Port of Dundee, hit back, saying the dock was easily capable of handling large-scale decommissioning work.He said: “The Port of Dundee has the largest permanent quayside crane, strongest quayside and biggest indoor decommissioning facility in Scotland.“Dundee regularly welcomes large jack-up rigs into the Tay and can handle all vessels any other east of Scotland port can accept.“There are only three vessels operating in the market that require 30m+ water depth, however this is a very small part of the market.“With additional investment, the approach channel to the port could be enhanced.”Mr Bowman said: “It is disappointing to be told Dundee did not pass the first test, although the SNP has still yet to publish the details.”

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make a  to the city.The 50-times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November 29.Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance to  to the national team at 43 years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park 18 years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although 33-years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September 2000, a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in 2009.The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No 33 shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £33.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet &amp Greet briefs – are on sale from 9am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.&nbspHelp For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

title: former dundee man steven caulker eyes wigan athletic deal
story: Former Dundee defender Steven Caulker is hoping to win a deal with Wigan Athletic just weeks after triggering a release clause at Dens.The 26-year-old still had a year left on his contract with the Dark Blues when he left on deadline day.It came just four months after the club had reportedly rejected a seven-figure offer from Rosenborg for the former England international.Caulker was a marquee signing for Neil McCann when he penned an 18-month contract with Dundee in January.Now he is training with Championship side Wigan ahead of a potential deal.Latics boss Paul Cook will run the rule over Caulker before deciding  he’s worth having on board.Aston Villa are also looking for a central defender and have been linked with the big centre-half, who earlier this month was reportedly training with Ukrainian Premier League Arsenal Kiev, managed by Fabrizio Ravanelli.

title: hamilton boss martin canning wont be shed a tear for under pressure dundee counterpart neil mccann
story: Hamilton boss Martin Canning insists he cannot afford to take any notice of Neil McCann’s plight ahead of Saturday’s clash with bottom side Dundee.Pressure is piling on the Dens Park manager after six straight Ladbrokes Premiership defeats and a Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United.However, Canning noted his side beat St Mirren 3-0 at home on Saturday for their first win in four matches, to give Accies some respite of their own.He said: “You’ve got to go and do your own job and my job on Saturday is to try to get Hamilton Accies three points and  we can do that we’ll be delighted.“That’s just football. We know Dundee will be desperate for the points.“We’ve got to make sure we match that and that gives us the best opportunity.“We’re all going to have spells when things don’t go our way.“I’m pretty sure, same as I do, he’ll believe in his players that they can go and win games and he’ll work hard to try to make that happen.“One result can make you feel a lot better.“I think at times last season, half-a-dozen clubs went through runs of losing four, five, six games and it can happen in this league quite easily.“I thought Dundee were good against St Mirren – very good.“The goalkeeper makes a mistake and they lose the game and from there it snowballs into a poor run of results, so it can happen so easily.“The flip side of it is, you go and win two or three games in a row and it’s a completely dferent complexion.”

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to give themselves an easier ride
story: Neil McCann has urged his players to “give themselves an easier ride” at Hamilton on Saturday as they search for a first result of the campaign.The Dark Blues have endured a woeful start to the Premiership season, losing their opening six fixtures and scoring just twice.At the start of that run was also a 3-0 home defeat in the Betfred Cup to Ayr United, making it seven defeats on the trot.In none of those matches have Dundee managed to put themselves in front and their gaffer is desperate for the players to at least give themselves a chance of picking up a result.In order to do that, they’ll have to get the better of an Accies side high on confidence after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren in match that has had a bit of extra spice over the past few years.And despite extra pressure on him to get the result, Neil still has faith in his side.He said: “It’s a huge game, they always have been against Hamilton.“The games against Livingston, Hamilton, Kilmarnock are going to be so important and then Hibs and Hearts.“We are still striving for that first win and we’ll keep trying to give everything to get ourselves that first goal that can at least put ourselves in a position to go and get that first win.“I still think that you could see in the first 45 minutes last Saturday, there is a team there.“I would just love to see them give themselves an easier ride by putting themselves in front.”The Dens gaffer is also hopeful of having some extra bodies back fit after a punishing injury-hit spell.Josh Meekings, Genseric Kusunga, Nathan Ralph and Sofien Moussa all missed the defeat to Hibs with injury while Kenny Miller was suspended.He’ll also miss Saturday’s trip to Hamilton while Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all added to the injury worries last weekend.The good news is winger Roarie Deacon is nearing a  after getting 45 minutes under his belt in a bounce game this week.Neil added: “We’ve not had an easy run of it and it’s been tough to get a settled side out.“We had Glen Kamara and Ryan Inniss back from injury lay-offs on Saturday but it’s been problematic in terms of that.“I have been happy with the squad,  I can get them all fit it would be welcome but we’ve not been able to get that.”

title: taysiders getting happier while fife folk becoming more anxious report
story: People living across Tayside are getting happier while those in Fe have experienced a signicant rise in anxiety, according to a report by the Office for National Statistics.Angus has seen the biggest jump in happiness anywhere in the region with a 2.7% increase on the previous year.During the same period, Dundee saw a rise of 0.9%, while Perth and Kinross experienced a dip of 1%.Fe also suffered a decrease in happiness, dropping 0.9% following a sharp rise the year before, but charted a further decline across the three other wellbeing factors covered in the report.The report notes key influences that determine overall happiness, including local factors such as crime, community cohesion, employment and education.People living in the Western Isles were found to be the happiest anywhere in the country, while those in the Highlands were the happiest on the mainland.Scotland remains the second happiest nation in the UK overall, second only to Northern Ireland, with England taking up last place.Scots are 0.7% happier than they were in 2016-17 but the data shows a decrease in the longer term, with a 2.6% fall since the earliest records in 2011-12.Dundee saw a 3.2% rise in le satisfaction and a 3.4% increase in terms of how worthwhile people think their actions are, but also experienced a sharp rise in anxiety levels.Locals in Dundee experienced an 8.9% increase from the previous year, with only Fe reporting a bigger jump across the area at 11.1%.Toni Giugliano, policy manager at the Mental Health Foundation Scotland, warned that there is a “very clear link” between areas with high levels of social deprivation and mental ill-health.

title: we are not manchester city csaba explains why he feels being dundee united boss is the hardest job in scottish football
story: There were some cursory glances around the Press room at the Falkirk Stadium after Dundee United’s 2-0 win on Saturday when boss Csaba Laszlo, almost out of nowhere, asserted the following.“The most dficult job in the Scottish Championship, or Scottish football at the moment, is to be the manager of Dundee United.”He qualied that statement by adding that it is also dficult for his players to pull on the black and tangerine but his remarks did pique the interests of those gathered.It wasn’t so much disagreement or astonishment that filled the room but more a sense of being taken aback by the brutal honesty of a man who has been under such pressure of late.He eased some of the weight on his shoulders with the result at Falkirk under what were strange circumstances – namely going up against predecessor Ray McKinnon in the opposite dugout for a side sitting bottom and pointless.And it was clear that, despite assertions by some that Csaba is daft or clueless, he was very aware of the ramications had he not got the right result.“We showed good team spirit under pressure, they handled it positively,” Csaba commented as he laid out his case to the gathered press.“Now we can close this chapter and look ahead to the next game which will be very dficult.“This is the third season where the fans have been disappointed to be in the second tier and we are talking about a very massive, strong and passionate club that wants to be in Premiership.“If something doesn’t go right immediately you have noise which is OK but we don’t want to hide behind anything.“We have this pressure and we have to accept.“We don’t want to spend one more year in the Championship – it’s not good.“The Dundee United fans don’t want to hear that from the board, the manager or anybody. They want to have the target of promotion and winning the league.“This is pressure, this is normal but you have to understand we have a budget that isn’t any higher than other teams in the main.“You have to bring a team together. We had 19 players leave and 16 players come in for the new season.“We can’t click our fingers and have the team work fantastically.“There are rules at the club about how many or which kind of players we can bring in within our budget.“It is not easy, we are not Manchester City with an owner behind you who can give you £20 million to go and spend.“We have to work with the budget we have to get the best for the club.“The Dundee United board have done a fantastic job. It is not easy to convince players from abroad to come to the Scottish Championship with everything else around.”It was quite a defence – but probably one that was coming after weeks of trying to keep a lid on it following poor results against Alloa and Morton.Yes, he has not had his troubles to seek with injury and scrutiny from all angles but it seems to be just the beginning for Csaba in his most tough of jobs.In the next four weeks they take on title rivals Ross County, Ayr United, Partick Thistle and Inverness. They kick off that run at home to County on Saturday.“I don’t just look at one game being more important than the other because you can’t afford to take any game lightly,” Csaba added. “You have to take every opponent seriously, whether they be at the top, middle or bottom of the league.”

title: xplore bosses apologise for disruption to dundee buses due to driver shortage
story: BUS bosses have apologised following claims dozens of services have been cancelled in the last few weeks.Xplore Dundee says a shortage of drivers is causing serious disruption to routes throughout the city.One passenger claims he spent almost an hour waiting for a service as a result.The Tele understands dozens of cancellations have occurred, with many being announced on electronic boards at bus stops.Normal service is still to resume, but a spokeswoman for Xplore Dundee said they are “seeing improvements”.She said: “We’re sorry for the disruption currently affecting some of the services in our network and for any inconvenience caused to customers. We’re currently experiencing operational dficulties due to a temporary driver shortage. This issue is being actively worked on and we are already seeing improvements.“To keep passengers up to date, the real time information boards within shelters are programmed to show any change to services. All the relevant authorities have been informed of this situation and are being updated regularly on our progress.“Once again, we apologise for this short-term reduction in service and want to reassure customers we’re working very hard to resolve this as quickly as we can to resume normal operations.”A spokesman for the Traffic Commissioner’s office, which deals with complaints relating to bus operators, said they were aware of the current issues in relation to the punctuality of Xplore Dundee services but could not comment on a pending case.Back in June, the Traffic Commissioner fined Xplore Dundee £8,700 after repeated complaints about late and early-running services throughout the city.A report was submitted by Bus Users Scotland about punctuality failings and the services cited included the 9, 10, 15, 17 and 23 buses.The financial penalty was imposed after the Traffic Commissioner opted not to pursue a further investigation into the issues.One bus user, who wished to remain anonymous, said he found himself waiting almost an hour for a bus to Charleston last week. He said: “Journeys are basically going missing as far as I can see.“I have a family member who works for Xplore and it seems drivers are going off sick and they can’t replace them.“Myself and other people have been waiting up to an hour for buses – it’s shocking.“It was only the other week that I was waiting on a bus to go to Charleston and all I was seeing on the electronic board was that it had been cancelled.“The company weren’t able to send another one on and I was having to wait, that really shouldn’t be happening.“As far as I am aware this has been going on for quite a few weeks now. There’s no signs of it getting any better but something needs to be done about it.“I was informed that the Traffic Commissioner was aware of it so hopefully they will take it seriously.”
